description:
it was delicious the best pupusasI ever ate!
it is a clean family environment with great food that welcomes the public to come enjoy a foreign taste
it was good yeah yeah!
author: Jeff T.

description:
Best papusas I've had in the city so far! They were super cheap and really large (about 2 could fill me up easily, 3 if I was really hungry). I ordered the revuelto con frijoles and chiccaron papusas. I preferred the former as it had a lot more flavor while the chiccaron was just meat (which I should have expected...). The place was pretty crowded, but it didn't look like people were waiting for a table so I'd say the turnover rate is pretty reasonable. 

Only thing I was a bit disappointed by was the horchata which tasted watered down yet full of an unusual spice. It might be the Morro seed or something else that was not typical in Mexican horchata but i was not a fan. Overall really liked the place and would come back for cheap and tasty papusas.
author: Edmund L.

description:
My opinion not worth 5 stars! Place itself is really small maybe ten tables at the most. If you do eat hear consider having a audience of people standing by the door watching you eat and ready to take your table any second you get up.

Food was ok but not worth the price . I can say their are tastier Salvadoran restaurants basically in every block on mission and have better pupusas and the price is about 1.50 to 2.00 a pupusa . Another negative for me was that it doesn't matter if you order two pupusas or five they only give you a small portion of curtido which is the cabbage slaw that goes with it and if you want more it's extra $$! Seems like Their is a up charge for everything hear!

Also keep in mind that if you order to go it's an up charge so I would reconsider taking out. And it is a cash only place so keep that in mind as well.. 

As for me I won't be coming back again but it was good trying it and giving you my honest opinion.
author: Mirna P.

description: This place by far has been the best Salvadorian food I've ever had! The pupusas were super delicious, great flavor and texture. I also would highly recommend the yuca Frita con chicharron. OMG! It was so good I couldn't stop eating! It comes with a sauce poured over it and it just completes the taste. Overall a great place to eat. Very friendly employees. Only thing is that it is cash only, but there's ATM machines close by. Will definitely be making this my go to pupusas spot.
author: Diana M.

description: I cannot even begin of saying how delicious the pupusas are at this restaurant. And that goes to say a lot because I do eat a lot of pupusas made by different people and restaurants. This restaurant is very clean, the staff is very friendly, but very small. Sometimes there is a wait for seating but we have no problems with waiting because we love it here. Many times we have ordered different things like the chicken soup or the eggs, beans and cheese or the fried bananas and never once have we ever been dissatisfied.
author: Diana P.

description: One of the best in Sf Mission District. Been coming here for years. Introduced so many. Pupusas: the best in northern Cali. Fried yucca...must have. BUT: the tamales are exceptional. Mission District is historic and alive.
author: Ken H.

description:
PUPUSA REVIEW:

Holy moly. $7 pupusas with rice and beans?! YES YES YES. I thought I could only get this deal in the South Bay outside of the city, but La Santaneca makes it accessible to feel full, not broke, and enjoy a warm meal in a neighborhood favorite. 

The only slight sad part is that there are only two veggie versions of pupusas, but that's perfect because their pupusa deal gives you two. I had the queso and loroco (wildflowers!) pupusas, which I highly recommend and will definitely order next time I come in. The loroco is a wildflower apparently, and the flavors are definitely more earthy and special however not empowering. The boys also got fried plantains which can be ordered as a side. Portions are huge and filling--my favorite! They serve water upon request and have juices and other drinks available. Almost everyone sitting inside that day we ate there (late lunch) was of Latinx background. I definitely felt like I was eating authentic food at a great price deal! 

The service was a bit slower than I expected, but the tables did always seem to be full. Servers were fast to take our orders, but the food cooking took longer than I thought. We definitely waited 20-25 minutes that day for our pupusa orders. Before we were seated, we had to wait about 8-10 minutes even during the middle of the day! They also have a cute restroom sign and very quaint decor. It makes me feel very at home. It's almost as good as my favorite pupusa place in the South Bay, but it stole my heart for being a great SF place for properly-priced-pupusas.
author: Jodi H.

description: Small place with most of the tables full. We arrived well since we had a toddler with us and were able to be immediately seated. They have a sign that says the food takes about 20 minutes as it is all made fresh once ordered. I had the grilled chicken which was a generous portion with rice and received beans. I also ordered the pickles cabbage which was cabbage made with an oil, vinegar & Mexican oregano dressing; very tasty. By the time we left, there were people lined up put the front door waiting for tables. I'd eat here again!
author: Terese C.

description:
First experience with Salvadoran food and it is close enough to Spanish and Mexican food.  This place is filled with locals so they must provide authentic Salvadoran food. 

Of course i have to have the well-known pupusas, prices are extremely reason $2 - $3 per pupusas with a minimum order of two per customer.  I arrived just before the lunch rush and waited 10-15 minutes.  The place is small and busy, need to have a better system or sign in system for a table.  Few customers just walked by us wanting to sit in the next available table.  

I order two pork pupusas, it is thick tortilla stuffed with savory ground mesh pork, it also comes with cheese and bean, or pork and bean. The texture of the pupusas is chewy and doughy the pork itself has a natural meaty taste, but not crazy about pork finely meshed.  The rice is light and fluffy.  Very interesting, I would say it like quesadilla with a thicker doughy crust.  Interesting food.
author: Frances C.

description:
Reviewing AGAIN because I decided to bring family here last Sunday and MY GOODNESS I fell in Love all over again and remembered to snap a picture (barely but it still looks decent lol) 

this place is freaking amazing!!!! I want to build a small house in the back so I can eat the pupusas everyday. I need it, I need it, I need it!!!! 

I got the fried yuca with chicharrones this time as well and DAMN it's good! That's the empty plate you see in the middle of my picture, clearly I'm not lying. Everything here has to be good, I'm convinced. I will be here every time I visit the city, thank you Mission.

P.S. this place is CASH ONLY! No way around it, but if you do forget there's a bank of the west ATM across the street. They take $3 from you so try to remember CASH ONLY :)
author: Leslie H.

description:
Some of the best pupusa in The Mission!! I dare say it, may be even in the entire SF Bay Area.  This is the real deal, as good and authentic as it could get!  La Santaneca have 2 location, another one in Bernard and they both get crazy packed.

If you are not familiar with pupusa, they are a traditional Salvadoran dish of a thick corn tortilla stuffed with a savory filling and served with coleslaw.  You can never go wrong with the Revueltas (pork & cheese) or Chicharron (pork).  If you are looking for vegetarian options, there's also the Queso (cheese) or Frijoles (beans).  Not only are they filling, they are very affordable too!  At only $2 - $2.25 each, order a few and pair it with some rice & beans or a sopa (soup) and you're solid.  It's one of the tastier and more affordable meal you can still get in the city!  

Aside from pupusa, they also serve up other traditional Salvadoran dishes including sopa, tamales, fried yuca/plantains and desserts.  Take a look at their drink menu too, they have some tasty juices as well.

While service is always friendly, do expect a wait and service may be a bit slow, especially during lunch hours.  Don't forget to bring cash too, cash only.
author: Janetto L.

description:
Now this place turned out to be really good.  It looks like a counter service place, but it's actually table service.  There's a sign up saying the food can take 25 minutes, but my chicken dish was much faster than that.  What I ordered was chicken with onions, which turned out to be three large and fairly crispy pieces of dark meat, drenched in a slightly creamy but very light tomato sauce just loaded with crunchy but adequately cooked pieces of onion.  Extremely good food.

Signs all over the restaurant said they were out of pupusas.  Don't know what's up with that.
author: David B.

description: Never had rice pupusas and they were bomb!!! Love coming here for pupusas. I should probably try other stuff on their menu
author: Bonnie B.

description:
The best pupusas in the city, maybe in the entire bay? 

Food: If you're committing to the line at La Santaneca you better be ordering pupusas. My favorites include the revuelta (pork/cheese) and the queso con loroco (sour cheese). Most people enjoy the revueltas and this one is worth indulging over, the pork is always tasty and the portion of cheese to pork is fair. The cheese and pork melt right into each other. I love the Queso con Loroco, though most of my friends are not fans and/or rather just order something else. The texture of the cheese is similar to fresh mozzarella, but the taste is rather sour. I recommend trying the Queso con Loroco at least once, it's very unique since Loroco is an edible flower that is specific to Central America. Take advantage of the $7 plate which includes two pupusas, rice and beans. Seriously major bang for your buck. I've also had ordered their chicken soup which is hearty and on the healthier side. 

Price: Super fairly priced. Portions are generous, prices are just right.

Ambiance: Lively, busy and loud. 

Service: Friendly and quick service without feeling rushed and like they're solely in the business to make money.

Overall: Authentic, tasty, affordable and just the best pupuseria in the area. You must try it!
author: Astrid Z.

description: Calling many times,  don't answer the phone,  after many times trying answer whit bad attitude and say if you want pupusas we don't take orders and hang up
author: Oscar V.

description:
Authentic place for Latin American food. Line can be long on the weekends but moves quickly. 
Tried the chicken enchilada and steak plate with a side of platanos. Everything was really good!
author: Coralie S.

description: Such a cute little spot. I really really liked the staff. And the fact that I was seated right away. The food was great and very authentic ...
author: Vika S.

description: The food is great! I usually call in advance to order my pupusas since i work a few blocks away and i dont have a long lunch time. But this time when i called they said they dont take phone orders. I told them that last time I called and they took my order. Which is only 3 pupusas, but he said no they dont, that i have to go in person and order. So i said sure! The gentleman who took my order made sure I got my food as soon as it was ready.
author: Avelyn A.

description:
Clean and casual.
Service could be more friendly
Pickle cabbage is just enough for 1 pupusas, I feel that they can spare to give you more.
Pupusas flavor was amazing. 
Give them a try.
author: Yohanna B.

description: There's not many tables so the wait is very long. Also, If you want to take the pupusas to go they charge you about 1.25 more for each one and they also charge you for the curtido. The service sucks. They never check on your table you have to look for one of them if you need something and most of the time it seems like they try to avoid you. The only reason I keep coming back is because they are the best pupusas I've ever had and also because taking it to go adds up.
author: Frederique R.

description: Bean-only pupusa for vegans. Rice + beans combo is a good value.
author: W T.

description:
The pork, cheese, bean Pupusa was amazing. The salsa sauce made it even better that it already was. 

I had the entree of grilled prawns with garlic and mushroom. It was in a herbed clear sauce which had a scampi-like gloss and sheen which suggested a good amount of fats in it. The sides of refried beans and seasoned rice rounded out what was a truly delicious meal!
author: Umesh T.

description:
Note: Cash Only

First heard about this place from an Uber driver a couple months ago who swore up and down by this place. He lives far away, but sometimes on the weekends his whole family will make a trek to SF just to eat here. Okay I'm sold.

Fast forward a couple months, and I finally had a chance to come here with a friend for dinner Saturday around 5:30. The place was full and there was no place to write your name, so we just stood in the entrance area for 10-15 minutes until we got seated.

We shared some pupusas and also a larger plate as well. Their pupusas range from $2 to $2.50, or you can order their pupusa combo for $7, which comes with two pupusas with rice and beans. The fillings they offer are mostly some combination of pork, cheese, and beans, though they did have one with cheese and loroco, which is a type of Salvadorian flower.

According to wiki, a pupusa is a traditional Salvadoran dish of a thick corn tortilla stuffed with a savory filling. I've never had one before and didn't know what to expect, but I loved the chicharron pupusa I got with pork only. They're definitely on the smaller side, but the chicharron filling was generous and perfectly seasoned. If I had been hungrier, I definitely would have ordered more.

I only took a couple bites of the larger shared plate--carne guisado (stewed beef with vegetable)--as I wasn't too hungry, but I was very impressed with how tender and flavorful the beef was. For $10.75, you get a generous portion of beef, rice, beans, and veggies.

I loved my meal here but want to come back again when I am hungrier for the full experience.
author: Dianna H.

description:
*CASH ONLY
This is a cash only restaurant; although not a deal-breaker , definitely not convenient. It's a pretty small restaurant has more of a strip-mall feel to it but it is warm. There's black and white framed photographs that definitely add to the ambiance and appeal. The food was good; there's really sexy waiter there with an accent ; definitely a plus! Lol ! All in all it was a good experience and I do recommend it. Lastly, I visited on a Sunday evening (around 5pm) it was somewhat busy, and by the time I was leaving there was a line formed outside.
author: Genaro L.

description: This place does not have much vegetarian options in the menu, however the staff was very helpful in providing/pointing out the right options.  We ordered pupusa with bean and cheese, and fried plantains it was very good.
author: Goutam K.

description:
Don't go if you're in a hurry. But, do go if you want good food caringly made. For as popular as this place is (it is frequently full at dinner time), everything tastes like it is freshly prepared.

The papusas are excellent.
author: Adam C.

description: Very yummy pupusas! So happy to have come here with my family! Very nice service! Excellent food!! Taking some to go too!!
author: Katherine H.

description:
How are you going to take your most popular dish (the pupusas) and stop making them for awhile because the restaurant gets too full? Last week the restaurant made the decision to stop making them....people go in and then leave because you doesn't want to eat pupusas?! Insane

Travel down to 18th and Capp for the recently re opened and remodeled Balompie. They always have better pupusas down there anyways. 

And hey, if the food is good, then it's worth waiting in line a bit for them. Right?
author: Jennifer A.

description:
This restaurant never fails me!
Always great service and amazing food!
Food takes a little long to come out and that's b/c they are making it fresh!
Always a pleasure to return.
CASH ONLY.
author: D M.

description:
Thieves. They do not provide you an itemized receipt. They give you a grand total and over charge you by as much as $20. 

The food is delicious if you don't mind getting ripped off.
author: Rocío G.

description: I love this place when I get a chance to come. The only thing I am not happy about is that I can no longer make phone orders for pick up. Makes me sad, but that won't stop me from coming in and eating pupusas.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Not sure why, but the restaurant has temporarily stopped making papusas. We went here specifically to get this item but they didn't have them. I thought that was strange since it's a Salvadorian restaurant. So since it wasn't available, I tried some other things on the menu. The chili relleno de carne (pork stuff bell pepper) was decent. The plate came with rice and refried beans and corn tortillas. I stuff pepper was ok, but I really liked the rice and beans with the tortillas. I also tried the garlic prawns dish with rice refried beans and tortillas and this was pretty good.

The restaurant was clean and the bathroom was clean which is a plus in my book.
author: Ali F.

description:
I love this place!!!
We go there once a week if not two. 
It gets crowded sometimes but it's worth the wait. 
They should have more small tables (for two person) so we don't have to wait so much. sometimes there is one person on a four people table, taking their sweet time to eat  just a suggestion!
author: Karla R.

description:
Surprise find!
My hubby and I thoroughly enjoyed our breakfast: Carne desilachada (shredded beef mixed with 2 eggs, bell peppers, onions, and tomatoes), eggs not over cooked. I had the Lengua en salsa, the tongue was tender and tomato sauce delicious.  Even the refried beans were tasty.  The portions are generous to the point that we had leftovers for another meal. To validate my point, my 15 yr old son scarfed up my lengua leftovers as soon as I got home and he has a particular palate. We will be back!
author: Diana Y.

description:
As authentic as it gets! Food is cheap and cheerful and reminds me of home cooked Latin goodness.
Service was excellent, we were even accommodated when we ordered off menu.
Expect to wait outside for a table. There is no wait list or reservation system so watching other people eat and being patient is part of the experience. Makes ou appreciate it more!
author: Danielle V.

description:
The whole experience was just bad! We came in and no one noticed us and as we sat down I tried to give one of their employees a sign so we get menus and when we finally got them he left without even asking us if we wanted something to drink. My boyfriend wanted to eat pupusas and we noticed they were crossed off from the menu and we just wanted to double check with the restaurant but we never got the chance bc they took so long so we left :( 
2 stars = I've tried their pupusas and they're decent but you can find better
author: Michelle K.

description: This is probably my favorite salvadorian food place. I've been coming here for the past two years and the food is so good, the pupusas are delicious which they were the main reason I would come here. Sadly they're not making any pupusas right now they haven't for the past month or two. I heard the owner took them out off the menu because he wants to see how many people still come to eat here even though they don't serve pupusas since they' cheap and they don't make so much money off  them. I'm pretty sure they are bringing them back soon. Overall very good food, but also very tiny spot, have to look out for people leaving to get a table and you sit yourself.
author: Genesis R.

description: This place is a gem, great food affordable price. Was in town for doctors appointment and decided to explore area, the place is small but you won't be disappointed. I had been craving Pupusas and these had my mouth watering. Highly recommend giving this place a try next time you're hungry.
author: Lance R.

description:
Came here after, after going to another place down the street that was closed. My husband ordered the chicken burrito and I had the pupusas revueltas. They were hella good! Not greasy at all! My husband said his burrito was very flavorful too!
The cons are they are cash only, and always busy! You can't expect to be in and out. Plus, I didn't like the fact that they brought my plate out first, and we had to wait 5 minutes for my husbands. That is very irritating. I can look past it, I hope it doesn't happen again. But I will definitely be back!
author: Jeannette C.

description: Can't order pupusas to go anymore so I won't be coming here anymore...I guess that's what happens when you start getting alot of business. You don't care about the people that have coming eat here since forever...
author: Bob D.

description:
I've only been here once, but I can't stop dreaming about the pupusas. Right now I'm drooling thinking about it. 

It's a little restaurant in the mission and the wait isn't too long. It's cash only which is a small inconvenience, but it's not hard to find an atm or bank within the area. 

If you're in the area, definitely check out this place. I've been waiting to go back since.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Decided to stop in because it looked popular and La Taqueria was closed. I'm glad it was closed because I enjoyed this more. There was a bit of a line, and the food takes a while (which they warn you about on the menu), but it was worth it. I had the huevos desilachada and really enjoyed. The beef was decent, the eggs were good, and the sides were terrific. Everyone I was with enjoyed their food too. The servers were friendly and helpful and the price was pretty good.

It's kind of awkward but also entertaining to wait in line for the bathroom in the kitchen.
author: Daniel A.

description: I have loved coming here for a long time and enjoyed their pupusas! When looking at the menu I realized the pupusas were not on it and so I asked if they were serving them and the answer is NO. They're no longer serving pupusas and didn't say as to why. Unfortunately, I did not stay for another dish because I come here specific for pupusas. I am more than happy to change my review to five stars if the pupusas are back on the menu, they're my favorite and very popular.
author: Orlenda C.

description: Excellent food in the mission. Their menu warns you that it can take up to 25 minutes for the food, which it did. But when the food came it's worth it. Simple, good portion size, and affordable food in the San Francisco. Really pleasant surprise as we wandered in randomly and really enjoyed our meal. Service was good and accomodating of our group.
author: Winnie Y.

description: I am so disappointed!!! I've been coming here 28 years and never have I heard we couldn't order take out. The lady who answered the phone was very rude. Hung up on us three times!!! We come here exclusively for the pupusas!!! And not being able to order them to go is ridiculous!!! Horrible experience. So disappointed. Management has to change back to the old times.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Best pupusas in the Mission! Cash only. 

FOOD: Ordered one of each pupusa and the chile relleno. 
- Pupusas each had a lovely ratio of filling to masa outer
- Chile relleno was flavorful and not too heavy on the cheese. 
- Vegetarian friendly! I brought a vegetarian friend here, and in addition to the standard veg bean/cheese or standalone cheese, you can try more exciting things like loroco (a flower). 
- Inexpensive and casual, but do expect a wait at peak times. Definitely filling. 

SERVICE: Very friendly--we walked to the back to ask for a table (not sure if that's what I was supposed to do) and were quickly sat with some menus. Servers were very patient in answering our questions about what was and wasn't vegetarian. 

AMBIANCE: Cafe style, with booths and tables filled with locals. A cozy place that's filled with a lot of families and friends catching up :). It can get a little noisy in the small space, but never overwhelmingly so.
author: Helen W.

description: I went to La Santaneca during Carnival for some pork pupusas and plantanos omg everything was delicious!!! The horchata wasn't too sweet and very flavorful... I enjoyed every part
author: Nika B.

description: Great pupusas but the service is a little slow. Definitely worth the wait. I definitely recommend you try the mix pupusas and the strawberry shake
author: Hugo B.

description:
BAD NEWS & BTW, I love this place!
I went to eat here last night and there is a sign stating they are NOT selling pupusas indefinitely after Tue!!! OMG - Also, that long line that I always wait on to seat, was gone, surprisingly there were empty seats, which that never happens, so I asked my waiter what's going on with the "no pupusas after Tue"? He said they need to replace the cook. BTW, the damn salsa for pupusas was so spicy! SALVADOREANS DO NOT ADD SPICE TO OUR SALSA FOR PUPUSAS, Santaneca you got that wrong. 
I am dissapointed
author: Cris F.

description: Really love this place. The food is delicious, and the pupusas are fresh and tasty. The other menu items? Also very good, but it's difficult NOT to get pupusas. I also like that it's open for breakfast.
author: Jason P.

description:
Chile relleno 
Bean papusa 
Cheese and pork papusa
Tamarind drink

$18

Not much pork in papusa. Seemed like a cheese papusa. The Chile relleno had beef in it too which was weird

Service is inattentive but they are super nice. Maybe too busy?

I liked it all but probably order differently next time
author: Foodlover B.

description:
My overall impression is that the place is ok, but not great. Maybe we didn't order the right stuff but the food was pretty average. The dining room was packed with Spanish speakers so I'm assuming the restaurant is at least authentic, although I've had much better food else where. 

We shared the fried plantains, one order of the meat and cheese pupusas, one order of the zucchini flower pupusas and the combination platter with chile reano and tamales. 

The plantains were not very ripe so it wasn't great. Maybe plantains just aren't in season yet. The pupusas were ok. They were definitely hot, but personally, I prefer a pupusa with thicker masa wrapper than the pupusas at this place. I felt like I was just eating melted cheese and not much else. The combination platter was the low light of our lunch. The chile reano was so salty and the shredded pork was stringy and there's not enough fat mixed in. The tamale was this huge blob of masa, but it didn't have any great flavored or filling. The best part was the retried beans on the plate. 

Maybe we should have ordered a soup or something, all in all, the food was average, nothing special.
author: Alice W.

description: There is no place better than La Santaneca for pupusas! I've been going here for at least a decade, had one of my 40th birthday dinners there (and then heading off to Mission Pie) and, now, try to stop in when I visit friends of of 24th Street BART. My/our go to are the revuelta pupusas and plantains con frijoles y crema. I heard that it closed recently, which was heartbreaking and, apparently, a lie, thankfully. Long Live La Santaneca!
author: andreana c.

description: One of my favorite authentic Salvadorian restaurants! Me and my family would come here all the time especially when we were taking my grandma to SFO for her annual trip to El Salvador. The food is amazing and the staff is friendly. I'm bummed that I live in the east bay and don't get to go as often as I want.
author: Simone D.

description:
Pretty fast-paced place to grub, but if you get the chance to sit and eat it's quite relaxing.

The food is pretty friggin' cheap--a plate with two Papusas, beans, and rice cost 7 bucks. Leaves you full enough to tackle the rest of the city at a great price.
author: Benjamin S.

description: I'm Honduran so I know pupusas and these are the best I've had in a very long time. The service was A1 and my waitress was very sweet. It was super busy when I arrived no seats were available but it didn't stop them from seating and serving me in seconds.
author: Claudio A.

description: Best Pupusas, plantains, and beans in the entire Bay Area. The beans really set them apart from others, as does the cheese/Pupusa texture. Love them!
author: Miss B.

description: My freind can to visit me and decided to try this please. Have to say just okay. Service forgot a couple of request we where waiting and waiting and never came  . Probably not come back again
author: Alessandra B.

description: The best pupusas I have had in a long time.  Authentic and delicious.  They really taste just like my grandma's.  Revueltas had the perfect mix of cheese and pork, and the queso was also so good!! I love their salsa too! I will definitely be returning when I come back to the city.
author: Ashley M.

description: The best pupusas in town! I've been to many other Salvadorian restaurants, but this one is the only one I always come back too. Great food, great service.
author: Milos L.

description: This is a delicious restaurant for inexpensive but so delicious pupusas.  The staff is so friendly.  Their menu has a great variety.  I would definitely return.
author: Dahlia L.

description:
If you're from the Mission, then you grew up on pupusas from La Santaneca. 

$2.00-$2.50 for pupusas.

It used to be all Latinos that came here, they still do, but ever since the gentrification of the Mission, it's become so popular​ that wait times can build up to two hours for a table and food. 

Wednesdays they are closed.

Thursdays are not as busy.

Cash only. 

Everything is on point here. If you love Salvadoran comida, then this is the place for you.
author: Angela B.

description: Have eaten here several times, always packed but never a long wait. Filled with families, multi-generational tables (and a refreshing, conspicuous, lack of Mission hipsters. Sorry, Mission hipsters). The food is exceptional. Menu has mix of Mexican & Salvadoran dishes, thoughtfully prepared w/ the 3 ladies cooking taking their time. Standouts, obviously, pupusas. The pork chili relleno is amazing. Soups are terrific as is the banana shake...not too sweet, super refreshing on a hot day. New favorite for Mission sit-down.
author: Jason W.

description: I know that Yelp likes long reviews, but in this case I'm just going to say a few words. Incredible, fantastic, delicious, delectable, and yummy yummy yummy.
author: Scott B.

description: As an SF native who has been eating here since the 90's, this spot is legendary for making THE ABSOLUTE, HANDS-DOWN BEST BEST BEST pupusas in town! The Pupusas Revueltas (pork + cheese) are my go-to every visit. Also can't get enough of the fried plantains with refried beans and sour cream and the house-made horchata. Also, super cheap! I am a lifetime customer!!
author: K. V.

description: 3 stars for the bad service. Long wait times, no hostess or check in, so they will end up taking your order after they take about 4 other tables orders of people that walked in after you.
author: Chelly R.

description: DELICIOUS! Very clean place.Been coming here for years. The pupusas are the best. I always get the pork and cheese with rice and beans. Recently I discovered YUCA FRITA & PORK :) and the following week I couldn't stop thinking about it so came back.... wish I lived closer I would eat here more than twice a week....
author: Sara C.

description: These pupusas are so tasty. I don't understand how. It's such a simple unassuming dish, but it sure packs a punch. Rice and beans are very flavorful. Wasn't a huge fan of the beef guisado (there was too much meat and it was kind of a rough texture), but I generally don't like chunks of lean meat. Service is fast, not crowded at 8pm Thursday.
author: Joyce Man H.

description:
At $2 per pupusa, it's a pretty good deal. The pupusas are a decent size, and they give you a fair amount of cabbage and salsa along with it. Two were definitely enough for me, and I was a hungry mo fo.

Tried the revuelta (pork and cheese) and the bean and cheese. They have awesome beans here. So while I liked the revuelta, the bean and cheese was my fave.

The only downside (not a complaint) is that it takes a fair amount of time to get your food. They warn you of this on their menu (25 minutes, they say), but still, when you're starving, each moment that another table's food streaks by adds to the hunger.

Note to self: Next time get one pupusa and a side of beans.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Second time trying out Salvadorian food, and i have to say this restaurant blew me away! The plates my husband and I got where absolutely delicious!! As I'm righting this review I'm getting hungry just thinking of it lol..

I wanted to really give this place 5 stars, however there poor service got them only 4 stars. When we arrived the place was packed so we waited outside for good 25 min. FYI no place to sit and wait. Upon being seated they also took for ever to take our order and we asked for napkins twice they never brought them my husband had to get up and get them himself. 

Overall the food was great! Would definitely come back . food is so good!
author: cecilia m.

description: Really bad service 4$ each pupusa when you ask to go that's robbery 2.50$ if you eat their that makes no sense really bad
author: R S.

description:
Decided to write an updated review for this place since I was able to visit and dine-in with them this past Saturday night. My friend and I walked in around 5 pm and were able to snag a table right away. They gave us menus and we ordered pretty promptly - it did take about 40 mins for our food to get to our table, but that's how you know they're putting love into the pupusas and that they are freshly made. We ordered the revuelta (pork and cheese), chicarron (pork only), and the queso con loroco  - each at about $2.00 a piece.

The four stars are for the food and the food MAINLY- the service we received from the 40-something balding server was below mediocre and he ignored me more than once for certain requests. The younger server was more attentive with refilling our cabbage and salsa/sauce, but other than that, this place strong suit definitely is the food and not the service. 

I'm retracting my last review, and I will  definitely come back to have some pupusas, especially because they're literally right in front of the 24th Street Bart entrance, but I wouldn't expect 5 star service.
author: Kathleene E.

description:
I love me a good pupusa. $2 per? So down. Minimum 2? No problem, wanted to get 2 anyways! Cash only btw.

The place is pretty small but it could seat probably 50 people. Service was great. Except the waiter got my order wrong... kind of mad but forced me to try something new so that was ok... Food takes about 25 minutes to prepare so be wary of that.

I tried a Revuelta (pork and cheese) $2, Revuelta con Frijol (pork with cheese and beans) $2.25, and Cheese and loroco. The revueltas were oily but delicious. The one with beans didn't have a lot of beans. Probably about a tablespoon of beans. Loroco was definitely different. It was cheese but heavier in taste. There's no actual flower in it. My buddy tells me it's a spice.

Like pupusas and don't have money to spend but have a lot of time, come try this place! I recommend the Revuelta con Frijol.
author: Benita M.

description: I like that you get to try a bunch of different plates at a tapas restaurant with friends, I don't like how sometimes you leave still a little bit hungry cause the portions are so small. The vibe is very good for groups with lots of chatter, but I wouldn't rate it high for value.
author: Dion L.

description: Omg. These are the best pupusas ever. You will never find any that are better than the pupusas in this place. I have been coming here for a long time. This is the spot if you ever have that craving. The only thing is that it is always super crowded, but worth the wait.
author: Mila R.

description: Gotta get here early or you'll wait forever. Authentic place where most patrons are Latino. Cash only, super affordable place with rich food and incredible waiters! Come here every weekend and love it!
author: Anees L.

description: The worst place to greasy. And they dont care I told the waitress I she didn't bother to ask to change just paid and that's it. Don't waste your money.
author: Jorge O.

description: This place hidden on Mission in San Francisco was a gem!!!! Small place, not a lot of seating so if you go right at lunch time it may be busy!!! But if you love caldos and popusas, this is the place to be! And it's very affordable. My two sisters and I went and the total bill was only $40! We each had a plate with rice and beans and 2 popusas. Plus a plate of caldob de camaron. The chicharon popusas are amazing! And the cabbage salad and salsa to go with it is so good. The caldo de camaron had great flavor. Just the way our mom use to make it! Highly recommend this place. It is in a very busy part of Frisco but worth it! The only reason this didn't get 5 stars is because the service was lacking. We walked in and we're waiting to get seated and didn't get a hello, we'll be right with you..... nothing so we decided to seat ourselves as soon as a table was available.
author: Fabiola P.

description:
Protip: Cash only!

Our original dinner spot had a super long line and we didn't want to wait so we ended up here for dinner, but I wasn't too sad about.

I ordered 3 pupusas and also the fried plantains and it was more than enough food for me. I got: revueltas (cheese and pork), queso (cheese only) and chicharron (pork only) and they were all really good. The pork was tender and had good flavor and whatever the cheese is was really good! It also comes with some cabbage that you can put on top to eat it with. 

The fried plantains (bananas) were really good too. It's pretty much caramelized bananas and I loved the crispier ones. It's really when it's hot and a really good dessert since it's so sweet.

Overall, I'm definitely a fan.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Great papusas, really nice staff, and close to public transit.
author: Allison S.

description: The service was excellent, the restaurant was clean and well organized. The food was DELICIOUS!!! I can't wait to go back!
author: Nae F.

description: One more excellent meal served fast and efficiently in this Salvadorean restaurant (not sure why it's classed as Mexican on Yelp). Unreasonable complaints about service here are mostly centered around the merciful lack of obsequiousness by the servers. They're very busy and have no time for empty, feel-good comments to please spoiled newcomers. This place has been around for the 25 years I've lived here and has never disappointed, never changed. Let it continue to be so.
author: Joseph M.

description:
As a San Francisco native who grew up just a few blocks from here, these are the best in the city! Pupusas are authentic, fresh and cheap- can't get better than that! Friendly staff as well. Notes: Cash only and the service takes a while (Because they make everything fresh) so order ahead to-go if you're in a hurry. 
Highly recommend! This is a must try!
author: Elena A.

description: We followed the hype from other reviews and the pupusas were incredible. Also really liked the beef with vegetables soup.
author: Raymond J.

description:
Took me months to finally write a review about this place. It was my first time going here and my brother recommended to tries their pupusa since it was one if his favorite dish at this restaurant. I decided to 2 combo Pupusa (consists of beans, cheese, and pork). Cost $2 each for the combination. If you just wants cheese, pork, or cheese by itself, it costs 1.75. Pretty cheap for pupusas. Also had this one soup that had scramble eggs and mexican sausage. Don't remember the price, but it was a pretty good soup.. If you put in the lemon in the soup, it taste very lemony and hearty flavor. 

Its a small place but chill restaurant. 

Friendly staffs. but the service was kind of slow...my brother and i just had soup and a few pupusa and it took about 20 minutes or more for the food to come out. Other than that, i did enjoy their food. Will definitely come back again
author: Julie N.

description: Best Pupusas and horchata! We drive here from Sacramento just to have the best. The place is ALWAYS packed and people are huddled at the door waiting for a seat, but it is definitely worth the wait!
author: Dayana Z.

description: All time favorite dishes, all authentic down to the rice and beans. Easily enjoyed also with a horchata or passion fruit
author: Eric J.

description: This is the kind of place where you would bring your family. I ordered two pupusas and a beef soup. Even though the two pupusas contained similar ingredients, they tasted different. The cheese pupusa was full of rich cheese, some oozed out and was a bit crispy. The pork and cheese pupusa was not as cheesy as expected, however it did have a unique meat flavour.  The soup was large. It was not as densly packed as I expected. There was corn, carrots, and zukini. The meat had quite a bit fat on it and was medium in tenderness. They are very busy for dinner as they only have a limited number of tables.
author: James S.

description: Best salvadorean food around we plan our trips to sf to always include this place. I haven't tried anything I don't like!! If you ever want to taste authentic salvadorean food come here!! The place is a bit small so there usually is a line waiting to be seated but it's well worth the wait.
author: Nidya H.

description: It was okay. A little over priced. Pupusas were fresh, the empanadas were okay. Service was good! Wish they would've had more drink options.
author: Dee V.

description:
Wow this place is popular on a Sunday night. The entire time there was a rotating cast of people lining up outside the door for a table. But that doesn't mean it's crowded or loud or has long waits. We showed up around 7 and waited about 15 minutes and got a roomy booth for the 3 of us. 

Even though the pupusas are cheap and good it's not like a burrito place - this is an actual sit down with table service restaurant. If it looks like the tables are full just wait outside the doors. Someone will come get you when a table opens up. There's no list or anything. 

I ordered the revueltas and chicharron pupusas (min order 2 for $4) along with plantain fritos  ($5.75 includes creme and refried beans) on the side and a salvadorean horchata ($2?). The plantain fritos were okay. Almost underfried because they were cut thick and were almost dry in the center. But combined with the refried beans it was really good (I don't like crema so didn't touch that). The refried beans were super tasty. Of the two pupusas the revueltas was much better. My advice is to stick with stuffing that contains cheese. I would probably order the beans & cheese instead of chicharron next time since the beans were so good and the chicharron were a little dry. I really liked the pupusas topped with lots of the oregano slaw and tios hot sauce. The horchata was different than the usual Mexican horchata - less sweet and a lot more cinnamon. BTW, this was a ton of food even though the plantains were split 3 ways. I could easily make a filing meal out of 2 pupusas but if you aren't sure you can get rice/beans for $7.

Service was a little slow. It took a long time for our water to come out and they forgot my horchata even though I double-checked they had it when we ordered. Though once we reminded them it came out right away.

CASH ONLY
author: Jean K.

description: I love this place! The food is amazing and reasonably priced. I always get the pupupas with beans and rice, and then a side order of the plantains. Waiting in line for a table isn't efficient because there is no system--you kinda just wait around and remember who's getting the next table. However, there are those people that will come in after and still try to take the next available table without properly waiting in line. This place is usually busy so be prepared to wait in line. Lastly, this place is cash only. However, I think it's still worth it because the food is delicious! Great place to try traditional Salvadoran dishes. :)
author: Hwan L.

description:
This made my trip to San Francisco even better.  The pupusas were delicious and the food reminded me of my grandma's food.  My children and my husband lthe food as well, usually they are very picky.  

Even though it took us 20 minutes to find a parking, it was worth it.  The place is small and it seemed that it was always packed, that's how good the food is.  Service was great.  Definitely would recommend this place to my family and friends.
author: Iris G.

description:
Awesome pupusas! I got three pupusas - two pork and cheese and one just cheese and they were phenomenal. So filling and delicious. The salsa they serve them with is so good!

Service was fast and attentive. I had a great experience in this small, dark quiet hole in the wall on Mission Street. Great place to stop for a quick bite to eat.
author: Christina M.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the mission!
They have the best Pupusa I have ever tried! I also like their beef feet soup! It is very tasty and I don't end up feeling thirsty after drinking it, which is a great thing if you know what I mean. 

In addition, everyone there are super friendly! 

I would recommend this restaurant to all my friends and family!
author: Alberto W.

description:
After El Zocalo closed their location, we had to find another pupusa spot. Thank god we found this place. 

Every time we've gone we've been able to get seated right away and once we are seated the line starts forming. LUCKY US!! 

The food is great. The crispy outside and soft, warm and gooey inside is just to die for. I love their chicharron (pork) and revuelta (pork & cheese) pupusas, for $2.00 you can't beat that. Their horchata is more cinnamon flavor than I'm used to, but its still quenching. 

i took a star away because their service is SLOW! Water refills are slim to none, and when they are asked for more curtido they take forever to bring it to you, that you have to remind them. 

DELICIOUS and CHEAP EATS!
author: Chrissie G.

description: This restaurant literally made my trip! Absolutely delicious food! We ordered pupusas (obviously) and the fried yucca dish. We tried to order pork tamales but they were out so I was bummed I didn't get to try it. Definitely the best Salvadorian restaurant I have been to and I have been to many! The only complaint I had was the service. I have learned the service in cali does not compare to the hospitality I am used to living in Las Vegas. Therefore, I will not knock down a star for it. Try this place! Trust me it's the best!
author: Eva B.

description: Probably one of the best places I've ever had Pupusas, crispy and just simply delicious. We also ordered pork tamale but their style is different than what I am use to.  I liked the pupusas so much we ordered 5 to go!! The wait for a table was about 15 mins for lunch on a Saturday but the service for food was about 25-30 mins after we ordered to get  our first dish. I suggest ordering an alcoholic beverage while waiting to kill time.
author: Buttercup N.

description: I've yet to decide if I'm a true foodie or if the fat kid inside of me just likes to drag me from eatery to eatery, but regardless of what I may be labeled as, I always manage to find bomb A** food like they serve here. This place is always perfect in terms of customer service, quality, and price range and they always make everything fresh to order. As soon as you walk through the doors you are instantly greeted with a smile by at least one friendly staff member who does there best to get your party seated in a timely manner. Once you are seated, the real fun begins and you now have the chance to overlook their huge menu of tradional latin food. It can be overwhelming at first, but no matter what you choose, it will be the right choice. I like everything on their menu, but always return for their pupusas, they are a nice size and so D*** delicious, and can't be beat for $2 each :)
author: Joseph A.

description:
Great budget friendly place for lunch in the Mission!

The husband and I knew we'd basically be snacking all day so for lunch we kept it (relatively) light - we ordered the "Combination Salvadorena" which consisted of a chile relleno stuffed with meat and cheese, a chicken or pork tamale (I believe we picked chicken) with beans and crema on the side, as well as rice and a small salad, and shared this along with 2 Revuelta Con Frijol pupusas (a mixture of meat, cheese and beans, the husband's fave).

We also had their version of horchata, which is definitely different from something you'd find in your standard, run of the mill taqueria. Reminded me of the sesame milk tea from Tapioca Express but with a cinnamon kick to it. I don't know how else to describe but it's worth a try. I really liked it.

I had to walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom in the back, and I noticed that everyone who was cooking looked like grandmas! To me that's what added authenticity to this spot: you literally have someone's grandma cooking your meal. Granted it took a while for our food to get there but there is a reason all the tables at this spot are filled up. 

We'll definitely try to be back for dinner. 

CASH ONLY! (There's an ATM across the street.)
author: Aivy C.

description: This was my first time having Salvadorian food and I was so so happy I came here. The popusas are wonderful -- I had the meat and cheese, cheese and flower, and the cheese and bean. The cheese and flower one was especially incredible. So reasonably priced, even though it was packed it was worth the wait for our noms to arrive. Definitely will be coming back!
author: Abby H.

description: This is the only restaurant I go to for pupusas. You can get a plate of two fluffy pupusas with rice and beans for $7. Where can you get a meal for $7 in San Francisco nowadays?! But note, this place is CASH ONLY.
author: Elaine L.

description: I'm a Salvadoreña, and I have been coming to La Santaneca de la Mission since I was a toddler, and I am now 30! Not many restaurants can truly stand the stand the test of time in San Francisco and this one has. That's how good the food is! My personal favorite is the pupusa "revuelta" (mixed-cheese, refried red beans, and minced pork). Another favorite is the yuca con chicharrón (cassava and pork rinds). If you haven't tried this place, because you are afraid to venture to the unknown, don't be. It's really hard to go wrong with pupusas! They will be a new favorite.
author: Raquel L.

description:
My friend introduced me to this place awhile ago, and man these pupusas sure are gooood. Sure beats making my own :)

It's a small place and the wait can be a bit long mainly because pupusas take a bit to cook. So keep calm and sip on a lovely horchata and wait for the gooey goodness of a cheese pupusa.
author: Em C.

description:
When you live in bernal heights, you become a pupusa connoisseur. I'm kinda a big deal in the pupusa community (in my own head). And la Santaneca (de mission) is the best.

What makes their pupusas so good? I don't know, you'd have to ask them but of all the pupusas I've sampled, Santaneca has become the gold standard. Not only because of the golden crispness in which they fry up their pupusas but everything about it is flavorful. The pork is salty and porky... Cheese is cheesey... It's a more intense cheese than other places. 

I've also had the salvardorian chile releno here which is delicious. Everything here is delicious.

Only downside here: no beer. And their service can be a little slow. But it's still worth it.

I will still continue my explorations of pupusas in this neighborhood and beyond. But it'll be tough to find anything better than la Santaneca (de mission)!
author: Bonnie H.

description: Love this place! We come from Oakland  to eat here. I have tried so many dishes and impressed with the original flavors of Salvadoran food. Be patient to wait for food, because it's homemade style, and always full. But more than worth it! Lots of people come for pick up as well.
author: Sara F.

description:
When you find a place that's crackin' in the Mission you have to be interested. You at least have to find out what the draw is about. I mean you are not in a location where el salvadorean food is scarce or any Latin American food for that matter. It's a place that's been going strong for years. I remember first going here with my mom when I was in 5th grade. I didn't quite understand it then, I just knew it was good.

La Santaneca is a good reason for my appreciation of cultures and food. It used to be foreign to me. Now not being able to go there when I want makes me feel foreign when I visit. 

It is only right that my wife visits here with my kids. This Saturday, it was my wife and the two girls. We came here right around 10am. Like I said, it was crackin. I went right to the front counter and asked little "pepito" ( that's what I decided to call him) if I could put my name on the sign up sheet. Yes, I know by calling him little pepito I have called him little twice but he is a little pepito. Anyway, he told me in his rude "scarface extra" accent that I needed to look around and see the line. He said the line is everyone waiting and I had to wait in line. I said ok, little tike but no need to be rude. I love the food here which is why I'm here but you don't need to be rude. He kinda apologized. Eh, I wasn't going to let speedy Gonzalez ruin this.

He made up for it by getting us a table pretty quick. Menus were brought out and we knew what we were having immediately. We decided to go with pupusa revuelta which is pork and cheese, fried plantains, beans and rice, a breakfast platter, and of course my favorite sopa de res (beef soup). Heck yes Pepito, suck on that!

I'll admit this is a bias review because it's part of my personal history. But yes, still bomb dot com. Only star I took back was for my little friend. I couldn't get over him. His face just looked shifty to me. The kind of guy that drinks too much wine at communion. You know the kind I'm talking about.

If you come here you have to order pupusas. They are so decently priced here and filling. Order as many different items as you can. I just love this place. I did get to speak to the owner and he is still cool. I didn't have the heart to tell him about cheech, pepito, speedy, pepe, you know what I mean.
author: Ryan C.

description: I've been coming to have pupusas here for about 15 years.  The food is always delicious.  The service varies based on how busy they are. Saturdays and Sundays are always super busy.
author: Veronica A.

description: In town with Salvadorean friend and the neighborhood pupusa choices were overwhelming but glad we chose La Santaneca. Our party had queso con friljoles, loroco and revueltas and they were all great! Delicious, fresh, airy. Cortida was amazing, too. Service friendly.
author: Nomad J.

description: I had been coming here years ago with my family whenever I visited SF. Lately I have been going to El Santaneco. I have only tried the pupusas at both, and I prefer La Santaneca De LA Mission!!! They taste fresh and don't over due it on the dough.So glad I visited this place again. I visited Sunday night before heading back into town, me and my boyfriend ordered two pupusas each and waited an hour!!!!!! The wait was ridiculously  long, but food was good.
author: Cin G.

description:
Probably my favorite out of the restaurants I've tried in 2013.

You know how people (perhaps only those in romantic comedies) have a neighborhood joint for meeting friends after a hangover morning? I'm going to opt for Santaneca as mine.

Pupusas are slinging out of the kitchen and the piping hot little pancakes ooze pork, cheese, loroco (twenty-five cents extra), and beans. The priciest pupusa is $2, so eat up!

The soups are where Santaneca really shines though. We've so far only had the caldo de res (beef soup) and the sopa de pescado (fish soup), and both have been perfect for chilly days. Big chunks of flavorful meat, lots of veggies, and the lemons really give a nice tang to the soup. I still have no idea what to do with the accompanying tortillas, but I'm working on it.

The atole makes a nice dessert too, and it comes in a big bowl. Corn bisque, basically.

Never much of a wait even though it's a small place right by the BART.

The fried plaintains are super popular, but I haven't had a chance to try them yet since the entrees are so hefty!
author: Kevin L.

description: Ended up here back in January and walked into a candle place and asked where was the closest Salvadoran restaurant and got sent here. Overall a great experience!! The pupusas were amazing!! As a Salvadoran American from LA, I did not know that SF had a large and accommodating Salvadoran population and La Santaneca satisfied my knowledge. Will come again
author: Anelle C.

description:
Pupusas: 3.5 stars
Fat, hearty and fulfilling.  We got the Frijoles con queso (bean and cheese) and revueltas (pork and cheese).

Sopa de Pescado: 4.5 stars
A tangy, warming and delicious broth with fish pieces.  Mum liked it so much, she wants to bring my dad here!

Chile Relleno con Asada: 5 stars
Best Chile relleno of my life -- soft thick outer fried batter, savoury pork filling.

Plantains y Crema: 4.5 stars

Empanadas: 2 stars
Charred black outside, with none of the doughy goodness you'd expect from an empanada, filled with a coconutty banana cream.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Food is good, but customer service is horrible. We arrived and had to wait 20 minutes for a table, someone that arrived after us was sat before us because they knew someone that worked there. When I complained to the employee he said that they had held a table for them because their family had arrived at the restaurant earlier and had asked to reserve a table for them. I asked if next time I could call in to reserve a table, but he stated "No, because we don't hold tables."..wow..you just told me you held a table.. I guess it's only for friends. I tried to give them some feedback on how they could improve their service, but the guy just looked away and rolled his eyes.

Anyways, the food took about 20 minutes to come out and we were never asked if we needed anything.

Food is good, but won't be going again because of the service.
author: Leslie M.

description: This place was fantastic. From the service to the food. It's pretty tiny so if you're claustrophobic you might have an issue with the lack of personal space. Still, the food was so flavorful and delicious. I will definitely visit again next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Theresa A.

description: Always great food. Be forewarned that because of its popularity and limited seating you usually have to wait 15-20 min for a table
author: Yasin S.

description: The food is okay sometimes. The wait is long for the food. And they confuse orders a lot.
author: Dora A.

description: started with a little wait , once we got table service started slow choices look delicious will post more may lose stars or stay a 5 service got better and captured all the flavors of El Salvador. And then I order to go drop it down to 3 stars because soda bottle "Kolashampan" was open and spilled all in my car who half way opens a bottle to go? I was going to tip however my friend did not like his plate now happy with 7 dollar tip was going to be 15
author: A M.

description:
I had the drunchies one night after partying hard on a monday night at El Rio and got dragged over to this place and fed and I must say it is quite excellent.

Yo the food here is hella cheesy just like I like it bruh. 

Damn food so good I'll come back and back and back and back again
author: Luke S.

description:
I have never put away my entire plate of pupusas so fast, until La Santaneca de la Mission. I was hungry, but not so hungry that I couldn't wait 30 minutes for a table on a busy Saturday night, or an additional 25 minutes for the food to be brought out.

My friend is Salvadorean, not that it matters, but I think it's cool to have your food ordered in the native language to the food you're about to eat, maybe it's a respect thing, maybe it's a street cred thing, I don't know, just feels right. 

*My New Favorite/Constant Craving/Human Need: Loroco Cheese Pupusas!* 

These bad boys are bursting with flavor and extremely HOT and fresh. I told my man that *if* he's ever in the dog house, he can redeem himself by giving me some of these, they are just that good. It was also his first time having Salvadorean food (What! That's crazy talk, I know!) so it was funny to watch his attempts at stuffing the cabbage slaw into the hot pockets.

Pork and Bean Pupusas are also a solid choice and had previously been my usual until the cheese only hit my tastebuds. I got a plate with rice and refried beans, very good. My table shared the Fried Plantains with sour cream which were bomb; not too sweet, good on their own and better with a dip of sour cream. Man got a soup with taro root and tripe: no one was a big fan of this, it lacked flavor.

I had a Horchata, which I am indifferent to. It had an earthy/sweet/dirt flavor/consistency, not that I've ever gotten down on dirt, but it's what I think sweet dirt mixed with water would taste like. Not the best, but live and learn. 

I thought this location was related to the Bernal Heights pupusaria but I got scolded by our waiter when I requested Chicharon when I didn't see it on the menu, but had recently eaten it at the restaurant of the same name in Bernal. Anyway I'm into Santaneca and since it's super Bart accessible I will likely be back asap. CASH ONLY, fyi. Enjoy!
author: Crystal C.

description: By far the best pupusas revueltas I've ever had! I ordered the plate which came with two pupusas and rice and beans. All of that was only $7! The pupusas were so fresh they were steaming hot as I pulled them apart. And the cheese was the best part! I'm definitely coming here again just for pupusas on the go. I noticed everyone else came for the Salvadoran meals as well and the place was packed overall. Such a great place!!
author: Brianna F.

description: Oh my. From the moment we walked in the place was packed! This meant it was not going to disappoint and it did not!!! Pupusas and hot chocolate is what my boyfriend and I were craving and it's exactly what we got. The hot chocolate was delicious for the crisp cool nighttime weather and the pupusas were absolutely finger licking good. Will definitely go back if I'm in the area.
author: Areli A.

description: Fast service and really good food. I'm a fan of the oatmeal pancakes yummy. The sweet plantains are always on point. It could be even better if they had handmade tortillas just a thought..
author: Zulma H.

description: I didn't know rather or not I wanted to give this place a 4 or a five. Upon entering there was no greeting of any sort. The restaurant was completely packed on a Sunday afternoon. So we made our way to the front counter and asked if we needed to put our name on a list and how long the wait was. We were told 20 mins, there was no list, and to just wait outside. Honestly it's so small in there that outside was the only option to wait but the fact that there was no sign up list made me feel like it was an organized. We were the only people waiting but  more and more people started to show up and actually stood in the doorway and outside which made me fearful that they would get picked before we did and there was no way I was going to allow someone to be seated before me. Once a couple left my girlfriend went in and told them that we were next which I didn't think should've been necessary but considering that they don't have a list it was. One seated the waitress was very friendly and attentive. The food was absolutely amazing and the service ended up being good too. In fact the food was so good that it almost made me forget the terrible wait hence the reason I'm giving five stars I would go back in a heartbeat
author: Cierra R.

description:
Delicious pupusas! I ordered the bean and cheese. There made with really good gooey cheese also pretty big size. The cabbage topping that it comes with goods really good with it. Order a side of sour cream, salty creamy flavor. The combination of the sauce/ cabbage topping/ sour cream is the best ! Love that they have glass bottle coke cola ! I'd love to try different things on there menu but I love there puppusa's so much I can't lol 

The place is pretty small and every time i'v gone has been packed. The wait is worth it. My boyfriend and I defiantly don't mind making a trip here when we're having cravings, we come from the east bay which is a 45 min drive. 

Completely recommend this place you won't be disappointed :)
author: Mayra M.

description:
Santanca is a winner. It is right above the 24th and Mission BART station. I walked in recently after going there since I moved to the Bay Area and as usual it was packed with other Salvadorians. ALWAYS a good sign of older Salvadorian people are there. I had dinner with my girlfriend and we had 4 pupusas and two drinks (horchata) and it was less than $10. Awesome. 

Their pupusas are top notch and in my top 3 pupusas in the city. My parents are from El Salvador and I have had thousands of pupusas over the years both in the US and in El Salvador so I'm pretty familiar with what a pupusa is.
author: Carlos A.

description:
So here's the deal, mi gente: if you want down-home Latino food that is freshly made by someone's mama or tia(or tastes like it), you will wait. And wait. and wait. 

Not to mention, this joint will be crowded.  You'll be squeezing past the locals and hipsters  to get in or out.  You best have cash or head across the street to the ATM(as I did) because they are cash only.  But then your food will arrive.  Tasty pupusas, great grilled chicken, good rice and beans. Well worth all your gripes.
author: Julie C.

description:
My friend was craving pupusas (who am I kidding, we ALL were) so we took a trip to this place to get some. 

La Santaneca is really accessible. It's only a few steps away from the 24th and Mission Bart stop. If you're driving there, good luck finding parking.

The place itself is nice enough. Simple decor, friendly people. 

We were set on pupusas so we all got pupusas and drinks. The pupusa menu does not have a lot of variety but they are all at a good price and in good portions. I chose to get 2 pork/cheese/beans pupusas, a Salvadorian horchata, and an empanada for later. My friends generally got the same thing. 

The food came in good time. The pupusas were delicious! Extremely filling. I could barely eat 2! The horchata was good too. Very strong with the cinnamon. The empanada was delicious too. I had never had an empanada like that before. Banana filled with pudding and fried? Delicious! 

I approve of this place. Cheap, tasty, accessible, authentic. They even have Salvadorian soda! So good!
author: Sofia R.

description: This is the best popusa place that I have ever been to. They have so much flavor and the customer service is never bad. Very good
author: Ximena N.

description: Pupusas are always on point! I also got the fried fish and it was delicious! It gets packed so be prepared to wait, it's 100% worth it! I love love this place! If you're in the city you must give it a try. Authentic salvadorian food
author: Jennifer M.

description:
The requirements were:

1. Needed to be near Bart
2. needed to be done in 30 min
3. had to be tasty

Was originally just going to go hit a taqueria but we saw Santaneca and decided to drop in. Hadn't had Salvadorian in a while so we got revuelta/lorocco pupusas, and the Combanacion Salvadoreno which had a meat relleno, a pork tamale, frioles, crema, and rice. Everything was tasty (except for the ricce), and  a ton of food to boot. For $15 a person we were stuffed. They were also super nice and it was cool to be  basically surrounded by the Salvadorean locals. Space is nice, even the bathroom is clean, especially for the Mission. notch one up for the list of fast affordable eats in the area.
author: Kim N.

description: This is the best Salvadoran food in the Mission! I've gone to a lot of spots, this place just takes the cake and then another cake. Huge portions, very decent price.
author: Lucas W.

description:
LATIN-AMERICAN FOOD CRAWL IN THE MISSION: Pupusa revuelta, pupusa de frijole

The undisputed favorite amongst my food crawl friends. For those who don't know what a pupusa is, I would describe it as a little corn-based envelope of magic, the magic in this case being cheese, meat, beans, rice or some combination of these. Pupusas are proof that God walked into El Salvador and went, "You know? I think I'll share that corn recipe I just invented with THESE guys."

I've had some great pupusas in my lifetime and these were among the best. Our group got the pupusa stuffed with cheese and pork, and the pupusa stuffed with cheese, pork and beans because we're uber-healthy like that. One bite and it was heaven in your mouth. Warm, soft, gooey cheese mixed with tender, savory meat in all its rich juices and starchy beans in all their glory, encased by a crisp, fresh shell....Ahhhh! I wants another one nowwwww!!!
author: Josephine L.

description: Worst experience ever!!!! Walked in with my boyfriend and baby, noticed that there were no tables available, so we waited by the door. A waitress walked past is and didn't even greet us or acknowledge us.  So my boyfriend decided to walk up to the cashier and asked, if we needed to find seating or have someone seat us? The cashier simply responded "there's no tables available!" No sh**t, so my boyfriend pointed out the fact that we were ignored and not only were we ignored but their response to us were "there are no tables available," and the cashier had the audacity to laugh at us. We just walked out, didn't even try the food. Worst customer service ever, I guess they're not worried about customer satisfaction.
author: Raquel V.

description:
It's hard to explain how perfect the pupusas were. The chile relleno with meat was also impressive.
The place was packed but we were seated in less than 5 mins. The food also arrived pretty soon.
The prices are reasonable and the portions are not small.
author: Xavier R.

description: I highly recommend this place. Pupusas are the best! Great customer service and welcoming place :)  it's usually packed but the waiting is worth it
author: Maritza S.

description:
First, this place does not have the best pupusas. 
Second, the people who work at this restaurant are disrespectful. Not only do they lack customer service they refuse to acknowledge that they are
Wrong. 

My mother visited this place last weekend and the coffee was horrible, my mother requested they change it and their response was "we have been serving the coffee this way for 15 years with no complaints. So we will not change it". As of that my mother said you know what I will nor be eating here today.

Again this weekend my mother went with her friends to give the restaurant  it another opportunity. When she order coffee the waiter told her "that's the same Coffee you disliked
Last weekend" in a disrespectful tone. 
There are better places to eat pupusas in the city. Like Los Panchos.
author: Ingrid A.

description: Cozy place, nice atmosphere, and you actualy have to wait a little bit until they make your food, which for me is a great thing..:-)
author: Rogerio J.

description: The food was great, the service quality was fantastic especially for the amount of people inside this small establishment. The food took forever to receive which would be my only complaint. That aside the food was surely tasty and I love Salvadoran style horchata. I could have done without the man peddling pens although he was kind and respectful. As always the Mission delivers great ethnic flavor. They were kind to my young children which is always a plus. My experiences seemed to be mixed when it comes to restaurants and how they treat families. It was obviously fresh and the Papusa's were made to order. This was the first time I've exposed my children to the wonders of Salvadoran cuisine, they enjoyed it. The plantains were made perfectly. The beans were tasty and the Papusa options were amazing. We will definitely return and I surely recommend others to enjoy the food and drink they offer.
author: Christina K.

description:
I have been eating pupusas here for over 20 years! Yes people, for over 20 years and they still have the best pupusas in Northern California. The place is cozy and small but the wait is not too long, about 5 to 10 minutes tops... las pupusas! hmmm they are delicious, specially the ones of queso con loroco (my favorites). 
There is a guy waiter and a girl (Margarita) that have served tables there forever and they are super nice, Too bad I can't say the same about a new guy that I had never seen before and if you ask him for something and he is not your waiter he just ignores you.
Other than that, still the best pupuseria in NorCal!!
author: Juan T.

description: The very best place in SF to get pupusas! You want real authentic El Salvadoran food come here. The have it all its very good place its small and only accepts cash just a FYI make sure to bring coins for be ready to pay for street parking but when you come here it's feel good to be in here and food is just that melt in your mouth good! I always come here for there pupusas I was taken here one time and that's all it took for me to love there food. This a must come to place in SF so when in the mission district stop by here and get some great food.
author: Chris H.

description:
The pupusas are a must have here. They arrive to your table hot and fresh and while simple, they are delicious. We ordered a couple pork ones a couple cheese, a plantain dish, a bean/rice plate (for protein and I didn't really care for the beans/rice although the sour cream was quite good) and it was enough to make the two of us incredibly stuffed.

The banana milkshakes are sweeter than I would have liked with too much whipped cream on top (I would have opted for no whipped cream had I known it came with it). 

Btw they only accept cash (Bank of the West across the street) but dinner was incredibly cheap for two at $20 and some change. We walked out feeling good and bellies satisfied.
author: Esther A.

description: The best pupusas in the city!  They make them fresh, so be prepared to wait atleast 15 minutes.  Everything here is delish and authentic.
author: anne m.

description:
They have $2 pupusas here and they were pretty good. Cash only though. I came in with a couple of friends who have never tried them before. The waiter who took our order was very helpful. It took maybe 25 minutes to get our food, but that's typical of a pupuseria. When the waiter finally came around with our food, it was the most confusing thing ever. He brought all the pupusas in family style plates even though we all ordered different kinds of pupusas. He couldn't tell the food apart! We had to figure it out amongst ourselves.I had to ask him to bring out the salsa and the cabbage that goes with it.

Besides the ok service, the food was good. Maybe next time I'll just order to go.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Pupusas? PUPUSAS!!! I LOVE!!!

I found this place via Yelp and went to try it. It was deeeelicious and very filling. Service was smooth and the food was everything as expected. The pupusas from my memory weren't too greasy and had a decent amount of meat inside to fill.

I would recommend coming to this place if you're a pupusa addict like me. :)

The only drawback was that it's CASH ONLY.
author: Christina L.

description:
Best pupusas in SF (tell me if I'm wrong!).
Authentic.
Better than a tacqueria (and quieter).
They don't have beer or booze, better bring your own.
Chile Relleno gets two thumbs up (because that's all I have). Same with pupusas and fried plantains.

I see somebody complained about the coffee. It's a Mexican/Salvadorian restaurant. Why would the coffee not suck?
author: Marcus C.

description: This is one of the most authentic Salvadorian food restaurant in San Francisco. Every dish I've had it's so delicious, especially the pupusas, always finger licking good! what I love every time I go to this restaurant whether to dine in or pick up, doesn't matter what time of day, there's a very diverse crowd inside eating and/or waiting to get seated.
author: Nita C.

description:
It was here that I discovered pupusas... And I have been in love with them since! The food is amazing (great pupusas and enchiladas!) and I like how there are Mexican and Salvadorian options. Also, refreshing horchatas! I'm from SoCal, so I came in as a tough critic. However, I must say this food is great! I will come back next time I'm in Mission District... Which will be soon, hopefully!

One more thing... Did I mention the cute bus boys? Haha ;)
author: Mimi B.

description:
I was expecting a real hole in the wall pupusa place but La Santaneca is actually cute inside. The wood walls are adorned with pictures of El Salvador. Of course they have a TV so you don't miss any important soccer matches. During my Sunday visit, every table was occupied and most people were enjoying big bowls of seafood soup served with steamed tortillas. I definitely want to come back for a bowl of seafood soup.

They had 6 kinds of pupusas. 

* Revueltas (pork and cheese) pupusa ($2): lots of porky flavor, pork was finely chopped, not much cheese

The pupusas were greasier than usual but I liked how the exterior was slightly crispy. The cabbage slaw was crunchy and slightly sour, with oregano and tiny carrot bits. The red hot sauce was better than average. 

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Restaurants are sometimes like people you meet them and you get an immediate vibe. When I walked into La Santaneca I felt a warmth and comfort that many 3 star Michelin restaurants could learn about.

This wonderful place serves amazing Salvadorian food. The place was mobbed at 7: People waiting to get a table for that amazing Salvadorian home cooking...we were here for the pupusas. 

I love their pupusa plate: two of these freshly made gems with seasoned pork inside, add lovely rice and beans...their amazing salsa and their homemade vinegar coleslaw and man you have an amazing meal.....all for $6.25. I had a mandarin Jarritos (hey it says 100% natural). There are many other great Salvadorian treats but I love their pupusas.

I must stress that since the food is made to order it takes a bit to get your food.

For wonderful food in an amazing atmosphere...check it out!
author: David G.

description: I'm a huge pupusa pig! Instead of dining in...I decided on 4 pork, beans & cheese pupusas to go! It is authentic compared to the ones I get from Costco. It was hand-made to order & worth the wait. Service was nice & the place seems very homey. Nothing fancy but still welcoming.
