One of the server has a strange flipped hair curl in front of his head which kept me entertained during my 15 min wait. I can tell it was going to be good since everyone who had the pupusas were busy cleaning their plates instead of conversing with their company. The relish was fresh & the portion were perfect. Definitely coming back again..
author: Kat N.

description:
La Santaneca gets a solid 4!

I ordered the bean and cheese pupusa and the pork and bean pupusa--both were decent. I've had tastier, lighter pupusas in SoCal but La Santaneca's pupusas are definitely up to snuff.

The true gems that my lady and I had the pleasure of having at this place were the fish soup (sopa de pescado) and their agua fresca drink called mamey. The mamey fruit is endemic to Central America and tastes like a cross between guava and pineapple, but inherently watered down---pretty damn delish in fruit drink form! 

Regarding the fish soup, the broth in this beautiful dish is so rich and tomato-y with that undertone of fresh fish flavor and fresh veggies, all in the mix. I'm not sure what kind of fish is in the soup but it's decidely a whole damn fish. So unless you're hungry for a ton of fish and not having another dish on top of it, I would recommend sharing.

Definitely juiced to try some of their meat dishes on the next go around!
author: Jason S.

description:
My parents are Salvadorean and therefor I grew up with Salvi-soul food. I know wassup. And when it comes to authenticity, this place is the spot! In all my days as a foodie, I have yet to find a place that does PUPUSAS like La Santaneca on 24th & Mission. One could say that they have ruined me lol

I've been coming here since I was a kid and always order the revueltas de maiz. OMG.... Where do I start... The cheese melts in your mouth and the masa is perfectly cooked inside and out. The chicharon they use is divine!! They keep it nice and clean and their servers are very attentive. It's a bit small in there so be wise with what day you choose to come because you might not be seated. 

The only reason why I didn't give that extra star is because the staff can be a bit rude and unfriendly sometimes. But that all goes to the way-side when you take your first bite. 

If you're looking for an authentic taste of El Salvador, visit La Santaneca. And don't forget to try their aguas frescas.
author: Julia C.

description:
UNDOUBTEDLY the best bang for your buck in the Mission and probably even the whole city. 

I'm not saying anymore because I don't want to reveal all the secrets.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Amazing! They only take cash which it sucks but other than that it's a pretty good place. 
The food and drinks are great! Feeling like eating Latin food this is theeeee place!
author: Vilma C.

description:
I agree, papusas are delish! I ordered pork & cheese - good size, I even decided to share it with my friend. And you cannot bit the price-$1.75 (small salad & salsa are included!)
For the main dish I decided to try Salvadorian Combo plate-tasty!
author: Ellie J.

description:
Best pupusas and casamiento in town. Not too greasy or burned. Just right! Very nice service too. 

No credit cards allowed though and there aren't a ton of ATMs nearby so bring cash.
author: Ryan E.

description:
I knocked off 1 star was because of the wait time. Although they were nice enough to seat us quickly, we ordered our food and did wait nearly 35-40 minutes. This was on a Sunday, which I totally understand the limitations of supply and demand, but I was a hungry little one by the time we caught the waiter's attention and had him check on the order. My friend and I both got the papusa plates (arroz y frijoles), some addictively good Fried Yucca (will make you think you ate cotton balls by how heavy you feel after), and the Fried Plantains (which were a little limp, compared to some I've had). 

I was full, satisfied, and had my delicious guava drank, to wash down all of the starchy, fatty goodness.
author: Brianna S.

description:
The pupusas in this cafe are to die for. I strongly recommend getting the cheese, bean AND pork ones. If you get just 2 of the 3 fillings, you'll miss the third. I am salivating just thinking about those delicious little parcels.

Cheap prices, crappy decor. Just how I like it.
author: Laurie W.

description:
I did not have the pupusas, but did have the Salvadoran steak, which I had seen someone else get and it looked delicious.  Mine looked good, but my steak was 1/3 fat and thus inedible, which was disappointing.  The part that I could eat was yummy, and I liked the vegetables it came with.  
Our server was friendly, but our food took over 45 minutes to come out after we ordered.  I can't be sure, but it looked like our ticket kept getting bumped to the end (based on my observations of the waitress looking at the ticket, looking over at us, and watching as the she or the chef moved things around).  There were five of us in all, and the place was crowded, but that didn't seem to account for the wait.  Several tables who were seated after us were served before us.
The place does have a cozy atmosphere, and has a lot of people working in the kitchen-- many generations, which gave it a family-run feel.  I really wanted it to be better.
author: Jen W.

description: Went there last night after we attended a concert. The food was ok. The servers were not friendly at all, almost like they were bothered by the people there. The server taking the orders didn't even look at the people when he took the orders. It was very uncomfortable.  I wish I had gone to another place.  That was my first time there. Will not go back again.
author: Maritza R.

description: Seriously the yummiest food we have had in a long time!  I had the Carne Adobado expecting it to be cut up pork in the red sauce, what I got looked like a steak and it was fanfreakingtastic!!!  Highly recommend this place!!!
author: Celeste O.

description: unfortunately, i was introduced to puposas at a late age and did not get to experience a snack that is not only fun to say, but fun to eat. they have lots of options for other snacks - definitely recommend the plantains and it's a good price for what you get.
author: Kate T.

description:
If you ever pour out of the 24th Street BART station from the escalator and head left instead of right, chances are pretty good that you've seen this place before. The reason why it stands out is that it's a Mission eatery that actually looks pretty inviting with the nice laminated wood sign and the cleanest-looking storefront on the block near the loudest-looking Mickey D's. I was particularly interested because a colleague of mine recommended it, and her significant other is a Salvadorean. How could I resist since I loves me some homemade pupusas?

OK, so I have to compare this place with my standby Salvadorean/Mexican place, El Zocalo. down the street. La Santaneca de la Mission certainly wins points on cleanliness and dare I say it, friendliness. They seem to have spent more on their decor here. But let's get to the business of the food. I think the pupusas are a dead heat between the two spots. The $1.75 Pupusa Revuelta (see my photo) was excellent, full of pork and cheese inside, although I prefer the curtido (pickled cabbage) at El Zocalo. It's just a little too sour for my taste. Next came the entrees. I had the Carne Guisada, a Salvadorean beef stew with major chunks of meat (see my photo). It's much more tender than it looks and less gut-busting when you make tacos with the hot-to-the-touch tortillas they provide.

Jamie W. ordered the Huevos Estilo Salvadoreano, which was a kinda salty combination of pork, scrambled eggs, tomatoes, onions and green peppers (see my photo). Both of us got refried beans, although both of us prefer black beans. I don't remember being given that option. All in all, it was very good, but I have to say I still prefer the taste and portion size of El Zocalo's Salvadorean dishes. They put dressing on their side salad, which La Santaneca most definitely does not. I also like the chips and salsa better at El Zocalo. As we know, the first impression of a place is key, and just like a blind date, you can tell whether you want to spend the rest of your life with a person or get a friend to call your cell within ten minutes to say the pipes just burst at your house. La Santaneca deserves a second date.

FOOD - 4 stars...solid Salvadorean and excellent pupusas...hey, where are the black beans?
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...clean and nice by Mission standards, for sure
SERVICE - 4 stars...very friendly
TOTAL - 4 stars...happy to have another real go-to place for Salvadorean
author: Ed U.

description: La Santaneca was good.  The highlights of our meal were the delicious pupusas!   The chicken soup with veggies was also satisfying.  The grilled chicken salad was overcooked, and the corn soup appetizer was too sweet to be a starter.  The service was okay.  Overall, a decent but unremarkable experience.
author: Barnali D.

description:
Great pupusas. Super cheap. Go and get pupusas - they are were really good but especially the pork and cheese. 

We also got chilies reyenos which were great and a steak dish (which was recommended by the waiter) which was not very good. 

I'll go back for some pupusas with a side of rice though.
author: Jocelyn S.

description:
These pupusas are fantastic as are the plantanos con creama. The horchata and tamarindos are really nice and the prices are great value. My family loves eating here and we've actually been coming here since I was a kid in the 80s.

I like how clean the restaurant always is and how the ladies in the kitchen wear hair nets. I like that I can see how clean the kitchen is, too.

The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because the service could be better, but it's a small restaurant that's always busy and it's understaffed. Also, cash only which can be a pain if an ATM nearby is down. Apart from that, it's a great little restaurant with great food.
author: S. A.

description: Outstanding pork and cheese pupusas! Very reasonable prices too. Definitely worthy of a return visit.
author: Ben F.

description:
I LOVE me some papusas!!! 
I am so happy I had time to kill before work and came here. Its always a good sign when there is a line out the door waiting for a table. 
I will be coming here again to get my papusa fix ;)
author: Natasha I.

description:
Great place to get pulpusas in the mission! This place can get pretty busy during dinner hours; so there might be a wait. However; the service is pretty quick and the turnover is also pretty fast. 

Pulpusas are only $1.75-2.00. The pulpusas is like the size of your hand. 
My favorites are:
Pork and cheese: I think having cheese in it makes it so tasty and the gooey cheese is delicious. 
Bean and cheese: also delicious and flavorful 
All cheese: It was good but definitely not as tasty as the pork and cheese. The bean and cheese or all cheese are great items for vegetarians. 
Only pork: This is probably the most disappointing one. I think without the cheese it can get a little dry. 

Other items: 
Steak fajitas: it was just alright. I thought the meat was too overcooked and chewy. Also too much oil; after a few bites it was really hard to eat. 

Note: Cabbage and the pulpusas are a good combination. They might charge you extra if you ask for more cabbage. 

Horchata: So yummy and different from Mexican horchata. I think it was less sweet and had a more cinnamon taste to it.
author: Amy L.

description: I wasn't super impressed with the Pupusas I ordered. The staff were friendly, the food came out pretty fast and the establishment was clean and efficiently run. This place is pretty small and cozy and could be a nice spot for a date night in the mission.
author: Eve R.

description:
Me encanta La Santaneca! HmmMMmmm

My friend and I both had the pupusas and we shared the fried plantains and it was the best dinner I will probably have all week! They are generous with the cheese, as it was oozing out of my pupusa when it was brought to me! PLUS their pupusas are CHEAP! Oh my goodness SO CHEAP! $1.75 for one! :O My only complaint is that I wish they added a tad bit more pork.
The plantains were tasty too! Guess I'm a newbie to this, but I had never had them with sour cream and beans. It sounds like a gross combo, but wow! It was FANTASTIC. My friend had a good point regarding this dish though: it's kind of pricey for the amount they give you. Over $6 for about 6 plantains on a plate with a dollop of sour cream and refried beans  -_-

The lady serving us was very friendly and she made sure we always had water. I really liked the woodwork inside...it gives the place a home-y, cute feeling. Like the bathroom sign!

Am coming back for sure! Cheap prices for delicious food?! Uhm, YES.
author: Kei H.

description:
Pupusas - the grown-up burrito? TBD, but they're darn good here. Even better are the incredible plantains -- which usually I find are too squishy and flavorless at other restaurants, but La Santaneca's are outstanding, a complete 180 from other places. atisfying latin american comfort food all the way. 

Not the spot for late-night bar hopping or anything to go. But absolutely a terrific neighborhood sit-down for a nice inexpensive unpretentious & satisfying meal.  Add in that its just a stone's throw of the 24th St. BART station, plus authentic not just to El Salvador (or so the other Yelp reviewers say) but also to the longtime character of the Mission (before its gourmet cupcake and artisanal water phase), and it earns its stars.
author: Kimbro B.

description: Ramdomly stumbled upon La Santaneca De La Mission and was pleasantly surprised.  We were seated immediately and our waiter promptly gave us menus so we could order.  We ordered the Bistec A La Mexicana and some pupusas to share (cheese, pork and cheese, and bean).  Everything was reasonably priced and came out in a timely manner.  Less than $20 for 2 people and more than enough food to leave us stuffed.  The steak was very flavorful and tender.  Pupusas were made fresh and having the cabbage and tomato sauce as garnish put the cherry on top.  I loved this find and will definitely visit again.
author: Christine D.

description: the best pupusas on the planet....we live in Antioch and travel all the way to the mission to eat here....my grandma has memories at this place and we have to make special trips just for her....
author: Maya L.

description: Probably the best pork chops I've had. I think I ordered the carne adobada, Worth the long wait
author: Ligaya P.

description:
After wandering around all day I ended up dropping in, grabbing a booth and trying out Salvadorian food... something I don't believe I'd had before.

My end decision? I wasn't missing much.

To begin with the service in this place leaves much to be desired. Beyond giving us menus and taking our order, we were largely ignored. My water was never refilled, even though I set it against the edge of the table and our check took about 5-10 minutes after we'd finished eating to come.

My tamale was tasty, soggy, yet tasty. But the real negative in my book was my enchilada which tasted... funny. It may have been because it was covered in a weird tasting cheese, or it may have been the chicken was too sweet.... or even that the sauce was just... off. But it was not very good.

Oh and they don't take credit cards.

No thanks.
author: Meg T.

description: Incredibly delicious, affordably priced and awesomely nice people. I've been coming to this restaurant since I was a child with my family and if I'm in the area this is the place I go to. You will be wanting more, might as well take some to go, too. Try the horchata yummy!!!
author: Daisy A.

description:
I've been coming here for almost 10 years now since my folks first took me and I have yet to find a restaurant that makes better or even on par pupusas than Santaneca. 

The place has changed little over the years and it definitely has a very intimate vibe to it. The staff is very friendly but only a few of them speak fluent English, which is fine with me because I speak Spanish. I could see how sometimes orders get mixed up due to the language barrier. All of the plates are authentic and the ingredients are always fresh. The price is reasonable but a little marked up due to their popularity. Pupusas used to be $1 at one time!

The location is very convenient since BART is right there but the location can also be a little ghetto at night. There is limited parking so I'd suggest taking BART. All in all, I see myself coming here for another 10 years and 10 years after that.
author: Javier G.

description:
Fantastic pupusas! Get the combo pork/beans/cheese, and eat it hot. 

Most of the plates are in the $11-13 range, but the two pupusa combo is a fabulous deal. Pupusas are big enough that one filled me up - if you aren't too hungry, you might even be able to split the combo with a friend.

This place was a lot more of a proper sit-down family restaurant than I'd anticipated. Nice place to go with a few friends to have a long catchup, or enjoy an hour or so (not just a quick sting mission).

Red sauce is hot hot hot!
author: Megan G.

description:
Came here a week ago after a Salvadorian friend recommended their "cheap, delicious pupusas!" 
I LOVE pupusas and although I am Mexican, can spot a really authentic pupusa and horchata when I taste it.
The horchata tasted authentic, the pupusas as well. AND delicious!
(I am not a huge fan of horchata, so I ordered a strawberry "liquado" (milkshake) while my friends ordered horchata.)
The liquado was ALSO authentic & soooo delicous! I recommend you trying one with a pupusa if you go here.
They give you a free glass of water alongside your drink so no worries of being too thirsty.

As for the pupusas, I tried the pupusa with all of the toppings (pork, bean and cheese) and it was delicious! (All like around $1.50 and two can fill you up!) Definitely coming back again.
author: Analleli G.

description: it was sunday and man it was busy. we enjoyed being the only white people in the place, until another hipster couple came in. they talked about star wars. we talked about how hungry we were and tahoe. we got 2 pupusas and some eggs and some plantains. man they were all really good and we ate everything and it was cheap and it felt real.
author: Matt J.

description: I visited a restaurant called La Santaneca in the Bernal Heights area and had a terrible experience. I'm not too sure if La Santaneca on 3781 Mission St and La Santaneca De La Mission are connected, but I have to say that I definitely like this location better. I can't say much about the decor, service, or prices because my mother brought home some pupusas from La Santaneca De La Mission, but I will say that their pupusas are perfectly piping hot, delicious and loaded with ingredients! I hope to make a future visit to La Santaneca De La Mission in the near future.
author: Joyce E.

description:
I'm confident in stating that La Santaneca De La Mission has the best pupusas in the city.  The Mission District has an abundance of pupuserias to choose from, but I always find myself coming to La Santaneca.  Undoubtedly, their specialty is making authentic Salvadorian pupusas.  The hearty dish has become a favorite of mine and this warm and welcoming restaurant is a gem in this Hispanic neighborhood.

The restaurant itself is small, yet has such an appealing atmosphere.  The walls are decorated with pictures of their native home, which adds a nice authenticity of the food you're about to enjoy.  Once you've been seated in one of their booths, a waiter brings over a menu and some drinks.  The menu offers signature Mexican and Salvadorian plates and includes:  tostadas, carne asada, soups, pupusas, etc. 

Regardless of my number visits, I always order the pupusa combination plate, which includes two pupusas, beans and rice.  I go with the cheese pupusas, while many of my family and friends go with revueltas (mexican sausage and cheese).  The food takes about ten to twelve minutes to get to your table and is always freshly made.  

The pupusas themselves ooze with melted cheese and are nowhere near as greasy as other pupuserias.  The freshly made masa really gives their pupusas a notch over the competition.  Additionally, once you slather the house made curtido and house salsa on your pupusas, you'll see why La Santaneca is one of the best.  The rich, yet flavorful, and spicy flavors get your taste buds going and is perfectly accompanied with beans and rice.  

La Santanecas's food is some of the best in the Mission and I can't help but recommend it to all my gringo friends.  The food is fresh, delicious, and price conscious.  After you devour your plate, be sure to spread the word; however, beware, there is another La Santaneca in the Mission, but is not from the same family, after all, there is only one La Santaneca De La Mission.
author: Alexander E.

description: Amazing place!!! The food so good. A try La Lengua en Salsa. Delicious!!!!!!
author: Rigoberto O.

description:
Cheap, good, reliable.

The pupusas are winners, especially the queso. I love the pickled cabbage that comes with them, like saurkraut with chile peppers. Nice heat to balance the savory. Platters are an amazing value, hugely portioned with beans, plain salad and rice. The food does feel homemade. There's a strong local clientelle and you know this place is a Mission institution. They 've done this for a long time and they've created a very special place.
author: Mark N.

description:
La Santaneca is more evidence that the Mission is teeming with cheap, delicious eats.

For South American cuisine novices (like myself), a pupusa can be described as a dense quesadilla or an unusually tasty Hot Pocket.  LSDLM's freshly made version features a warm, delightfully chewy tortilla shell encasing tightly packed flavorful meat.  Both the pork and the pork & cheese pupusas are enhanced by the acidic curtido (basically coleslaw) and mouth-warming, watery yet spicy salsa.

Orders to go require some skill to tackle neatly - the curtido and salsa are poured into plastic grocery bags, so any slight puncture can result in a pupusaster.  

Beware the temptation to order based solely on the pupusa's circumference - the density of the tortilla and meat pack quite the filling punch.  Two pupusas are sufficient for any normal degree of hunger.  At $1.75 each, LSDLM qualifies for a rare sub-$5 meal!
author: Andrew M.

description:
The food here was great but the service was lacking. They seemed to focus more on the customers waiting in line than those that were already seated. Example: I had to get up and ask for more water while they were taking orders of those in line. With only 3 people cooking in the kitchen this made them have a long back up of orders. 
I don't really think you can mess up pupusas. They were great! It's the only place I've had them in the city thus far and they good. Worth the wait and poor service- probably not.
author: Cesie A.

description: This place is the devils butt hole. It's hot inside, no AC. Slow service. Rude workers. Bland food and by far the greasiest pupusa I have EVER had. I might as well had taken a shot of pure oil to the dome. I would NOT recommend this place... Keep away.
author: Dina R.

description:
La Santaneca, located right across from the BART station next to the McDonald's, serves the best, most consistent pupusas in the city.  It is cash only, so break out the $10 bill for two people, because that's all you'll likely need to leave satisfied

For those that have never heard of a pupusa, it's a Salvadoran staple food of fried masala and cheese, sometimes with Central American bacon pork or refried beans, topped with optional pickled cabbage.  If that doesn't sound awesome alone, then you can stop reading.  We usually order the pupusas revueltas (with sizzling white quesillo and pork), and a Salvadoran tamale, filled with potatoes and pork or chicken, much thicker and heartier than your typical Mexican tamale.

A good pupusa doesn't get soggy, balances the main ingredients perfectly, and will always leave you satisfied.  La Santaneca does this perfectly, and does it consistently.   After trying a fairly exhaustive search, this has become our regular stop for pupusas.  The white quesillo cheese just oozes deliciously out of the pupusa as you make your first bite, with a nice stretchy quality you would expect from a pizza.  The pork is just salty enough to provide a good change-up of flavor, and they hold together perfectly in the masa pancake.

It's not the healthiest thing in the world, but you'll find yourself craving something you didn't even know existed after you're done.
author: Jeff Y.

description: I only give this place a one star because of their banana + strawberry milkshake. Everyone who I came with didn't enjoy their plate (they know Salvadorian food given they are Salvadorian themselves) one of them looked as if she was eating glass. I, who don't know much about Salvadorian food wasn't wow'd. Safe to say I will not be returning anymore. Sorry.
author: Jenny F.

description: I'm Salvadoran and im very picky about Pupusas. I must say the pupusas here were on point. The place is not fancy ......if you're expecting something fancy then go somewhere else. Not here for a fancy place ... here for some damn good pupusas. Their food is on point and workers are very friendly. Can't ask for more.
author: Ron C.

description:
I love this place.  Everything is fresh and made to order, very traditional. 

Pupusas are the a small part of the menu but it's what I get every time.  Thick corn tortillas stuffed with cheese, beans, or pork, topped with a traditional (and yummy) slaw.  Get two of these with rice and beans, and you will be set for the day.

Service is always excellent - warm, attentive, and friendly.  The restaurant is always meticulously clean, and shows that in every little detail these folks care about getting it right.
author: Scott D.

description:
Yummo!! Headed to mission st. after work looking for good eats that would be open past 8 on a Sunday. Saw La Santaneca and was excited to try their papusas, after having being an El Zocalo fan for quite some time.  I'm so glad all the other places that night were closed, because we probably would not have seen this place, my new love.

We ordered the two papusas platter, one pork, one cheese.  Holy lord these were some taaaasty papusas.  The cheese was gooey and oozy and crunchy in the right places.  The puerco was juicy and flavorful, not dry and hard to swallow like others I've had.  La Santaneca had completely revived my faith in meat filled papusas.  What I liked the most about the papusa was the dough.  I'm certainly no papusa expert, but I know when I really like doughy goodness and this was the best papusa dough i've had yet.  Pounded and mashed to perfection.  Not too thick, not to dry or chewy. YES. 

What surprised the most about the meal, is that we also shared the Flautas con Pollo.  When they say "guacamole and sour cream" they mean an entire fresh avocado sliced on top of your flautas with mexican crema galore (see: photos).  Again, the pollo was not dry, overly pulled, or hard to swallow.  I seriously took out the chicken, ate it on its own, and wrapped it up in the corn tortillas because there was so much goodness!  The rice they make is also great, light and fluffy, perfect with slightly runny refried beans, and a whole lot of papusa-flauta greatness  goin around. Oh and we got the platanos just because we had to, and that was also an unexpected surprise!  Not just fried platanos, but very deliberately friend platanos.  Good flavor, not too oily, and the perfect texture.

Two dishes, one side, and two drinks for only $25! No complaints at all.  Service wasn't noticeably bad, nor noticeably good.  All around great experience, good homey crowd, great food.  Take note, when you go to the bathroom, you get to walk near/in the kitchen and see all the magic happening.  The decor is fun, welcoming, and interesting too! Hope to see you here!
author: Rachelle F.

description: If somebody says that he/she doesn't like Mexican and/or Salvadorian cuisine... take him or her to the Las Santaneca De La Mission restaurant, they will fall in love with soon. I am not sure how much authentic the dishes coz never been to Mexico and Salvador yet but I believe they are. And this restaurant is a good reason why these two countries are the first ones on my bucket list  The food is awesome. The environment is really great. The service is wonderful. Don't forget to enjoy their drinks!!! Definitely 5 stars!!!
author: Denis U.

description: I love this place, there's only a few of their dishes that I order and shuffle around so I don't get tired of the food, but when I do order it's always good. The only reason I didn't give them a five (5) star is because of the time it takes to get the food they definitely need to improve that but customer service is great and I would definitely recommend this place to friends.
author: Arland B.

description: Two of the stars are for the food. But the service is HORRIBLE. We waited for like 45 minutes for the food. And that's not an exaggeration...I watched the clock from the moment we sat down until the moment we got our food. And a table that came in after us got ALL of their food BEFORE us. I don't care how loyal the customers are or even that the pupusas are so cheap (which WERE delicious) it's inexcusable to wait that long for good. Even more so when someone who comes in after you gets all their food before you. I don't think Ill be back unless friends drag me here.
author: Asia W.

description:
I was twisting and turning in my dream having a violent episodic fat pupusa craving until I woke up seeking treatment from this cute pupuseria located across the street from the BART station on 24th and Mission. With dim lighting, spacious red tile floor and wooden layout, this place is very clean, organized, and often filled with pupusa enthusiasts of all ages looking for a quick fix. I was here twice, once for brunch and another for dinner, and few can complain about the cost of these beautifully seductive pupusas at $1.75 each. The first time I had the pupusa revuelta and pupusa chicharron with rice and beans combo ($7 w/tax). These warm pupusas came in the shape of the moon with silky refried beans and delicious Spanish rice to go with sour curtido. My revuelta was filled with pork and cheese while the chicharron was hearty and plentiful. They were really delicious and reconfirm all the reasons why I love to get my hands on these big fat pupusas.

In my next visit for dinner, I went with the server's recommendation by ordering the combination seafood soup ($15.10 w/tax). With the broth sour and tangy that resembled a milder version of seafood sinigang, my huge bowl was filled to the brim with shrimps, mussels, large chunks of fish, calamari, whole baby crab, and clams. The concept was delicious with robust natural seafood broth and a degree of tang for the wow effect. The only down side was that everything still had its shells so the benefits of using them as anchors for flavoring was also a major barrier to a hands free dining experience. All except the baby crab which was difficult to eat, I absolutely love the thick pieces of fish that still had a lot of moisture and the overflow of clams and mussels was just outright sensational. In addition to the soup, I thought the side of corn tortillas was generous and decent, but the complimentary chips and salsa were a bit watery and generic. It was overall a hearty meal and something that two people could've shared. 

Although the food costs more than El Zocalo or any of the other places nearby, but the value you get in return is their persistence in keeping the place clean and presentable by wiping everything down daily, including the condiments. Service was slow and distanced during my initial visit but decent during the dinner. For the price, quality, and value, I definitely rank this place among the best in the Mission. I thought the soup was a bit expensive for a cash only place, but for pupusas I would rank them the same as El Zocalo but the lack of variety in the pupusas puts them a grade below Balompie Cafe.
author: Daniel L.

description:
The pupusas here are extremely good!! Thanks to Yelp I was trying to locate a good place for pupusas in the mission & due to the all the good reviews decided to check this place out. 
Thanks to all the yelpers I found a new place for pupusas that are absolutely tasty, especially de revuelta. Besides ordering pupusas, the fried yuca with chicharon is a must as well. MMMM just writing this review i'm craving one right one. LOL anyways, that's all i've had from this place so far, but no doubt am i coming back for when i need to fulfill my cravings for pupusas. MUST TRY!!
author: Patricia B.

description: Shared 2 pupusas - one pork and a cheese in the rice dough. They were both very good and came with surtido to cut the grease. It was crowded and busy but this was a great place to get a snack.
author: Marco M.

description: Only place I really trust with my pupusas with in the city and their pasteles are the biggest I have ever had and delicious, you may need to wait for seating sometimes but is well worth it...
author: Erick M.

description:
BEST Pupusas that I've ever had in my life besides my mother's long time friend. 
It's bothe Mexican and Salvadorean but the Salvadorean is the best part. 

I came here with a past co-worker for my birthday.  I also remember coming here twice in the past coming with my mother.
I had two pupusas revueltas wih rice and bean on the side and a refreshment of horchata. The best part is that it's really inexpensive. It's very authentic and have real Salvadorean starters as well as the food. Pupusas are at a low cost too...$1.75!!!
I will definitely come here for sure, guaranteed.
Also the BART station is extremely close.
author: Nadav M.

description:
Amazing food!  By far the best chili relleno and tamale I have ever had.

Really nice service as well and you can tell that the food is made from scratch after you order it. 

I will be back!!
author: Chad F.

description: More salv than mex but was very good. Casual restaurant, big menu, service was fine and food was delicious. Cash only. Lots of booths.
author: Will D.

description:
My brother & I headed here the other day from a referral from a Salvadorean friend and we both became instant fans.
This place is CLEAN, there's abuellas pounding away at the pupusas in the kitchen and the prices are cheap.

5 star Pupusas - just like my friend's abuella used make.  HELL YA!

Plaintains looked amazing, but we split the tamale &  empanadas (sweeter than expected, I'd pass next time)
Tamales were good but good tamales are a dime a dozen in the neighborhood, so I'll stick with this as my go to when I crave pupusas.  The other go to place got knocked aside.  Disregard my past review for that joint.

Other good Mexican places in the MisH, sure, but not a whole lot of good Salvadorean .  This pLace rocks.


Cash only, fyi - no biggie, there's only about 8 banks within 2 blocks.
author: Athena S.

description: Still loving the pupusas here, revuelta con frijole's is the ONLY way to go! The atole de elote is pretty friggin good too! Bring cash, no Credit Cards here unfortunately! : - (
author: Larry B.

description: Delicious food! And good costumer service!! Love this place my family and I come here regularly and have tried most of the menu and have never complained! The good is good and the venue is clean. If I had to give any recommendations it would be the fried fish plate and any kind of pupusa !
author: Evelyn Sophia C.

description:
This place nails pupusas like it's their business.  Oh wait, it is.

The pupusas are cheap, the food came out fast and, most importantly, they were delicious.  I got the $6.95 combo platter with two pork pupusas with rice and beans.  The corn tortilla was cooked up to perfection, with a deliciously tasty chicharrón, bean and queso filling.  The rice and beans definitely weren't an afterthought; they were very flavorful and complemented the pupusas nicely.  Throw on the curtido (cabbage slaw) and salsa, and you have a pupusa party on your plate!

Overall, the food takes center stage here.  It's a homey restaurant, nowhere like the "hole in the wall" other people are suggesting.  The service was great, friendly and made me want to come back.  In fact, when I asked for a to-go box for my left over pupusa, they brought over a small bag of curtido and salsa to go along with it.  It may seem insignificant, but it really made my day knowing that I could eat my leftovers later along with all the fixings. 

I'm pretty stingy with my five-star ratings (I'm Asian after all...), but this place rightfully deserves it.  Balompie gets all the attention for their pupusas, but this place really hits it out of the ballpark.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Bobby L.

description:
I have walked by this place since November of last year! How embarrassing that I never tried it until yesterday.

I had a huge hunkering for curtido, pupusas too ;-)

This place was packed, which was a sign--a good sign. After a short wait we got a booth and I ordered 3 revueltas with a tamarind water/juice. I could only eat 2 though!

Oh lawd, was the curtido good. The pupusas are made fresh (so they take a while), but once they arrived I practically inhaled the small bowl of curtido on the side. It was heavenly. The chili flakes really added a great dimension to the super warm and fluffy pupusas. Tamarind juice was perfect and made with the real stuff!

For $1.75 each, these pupusas are a steal and so worth a commute into the city on any day.
author: Hilda Z.

description: Best pupusas in the city! Love this place. My boyfriend (salvadorian) and his family took me here years ago and I have been here numerous times since, can't get enough! I usually get the loroco cheese pupusas, plaintains, and sometimes the pan con pavo (huge!). Be aware that there may be a bit of a wait since the restaurant isn't too big.  The service is always good and the food never disappoints.
author: Daisy D.

description: Takes me back to San Salvador though not as cheep.  The food here is great and it's super close to 24th St. BART. My wife and I like the food so much we brought both our families here for dinner the weekend of our wedding.  The only trick is don't  confuse it with the other La Santaneca further down on Mission in Bernal Heights.
author: Eric Z.

description:
Now i have been coming here to SF all of my life,and  12 yrs ago i was introduced to Salvadorian food(Via Old girl Friend) and i had my first Pupusa...Even today i make it a field trip with my kids just to go and have awesome food...BUT.....My one and ONLY complaint is that they need to expand...the line at times is all the way out the door .people waiting for a seat. 
And trust me the food is worth every moment that you wait for it.
author: Hector L.

description:
i've had quite a few things here.
I think the main courses are the best part of this place, I had a delicious pork shoulder that with a nice crispy skin. It's not too expensive either so it works out pretty well.

Though I also got the Fried Plantains were decent, I was kinda expecting them to be a bit more fried and less squishy than I was hoping. I've had fried plantains crispy fried before and it was quite delicious. 

The Empanada while the crust was good, the pudding inside was very bland. 

The rice also had some weird taste to it, like it wasn't cooked all the way but the tortillas are quite good.
author: Rohan D.

description: La Santaneca is cute, cozy and warm. For El Salvadoren food, I have to say I prefer the greasier version of it all further down Mission at El Zocalo - but I can imagine spending many comfortable mealtimes at La Santaneca - in their hospitable fashion they would never hurry you off - whereas El Zocalo is way too brightly lit, service is a slapdash affair, and the bathrooms are usually bordering on disgusting.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Adorable hidden gem of a restaurant in the Mission! I walked in here with some friends late one night after a long day; we were drawn in by the casual atmosphere (nice lighting and not too noisy) and reasonably priced food. La Santaneca truly did not disappoint. The pupusas are some of the best I've had (just the perfect amount of cheese, unlike some of the insanely cheesy pupusas I've had at other restaurants in the neighborhood), and they serve a number of other Salvadorean/Central American specialties as well (such as elotes, sweet corn tamales, fried plantains etc.) that aren't served at most restaurants. Also appreciate that cleanliness is definitely a priority for them, which definitely cannot be said for all restaurants in the Mission!) Only reason they didn't get 4 stars is that the service was on the slow side.
author: Chelsea H.

description:
An amazing place to come for some quality Salvadoran food.  Be sure to get their pupusas!  Their full plates are nice as well (especially the yucca), but pupusas are an absolute staple.  Lots of different fillings, affordable and delicious!  

Additionally, the waitstaff is very friendly and sweet.  Cute interior, easy to find and right next to BART.  The perfect city stop for some authentic Salvadoran cuisine!
author: Ivana T.

description: Have eaten Mexican (read: Tex-Mex) food my whole life but don't recall eating at a place that was officially salvadoreño so I was looking forward to having it for the first time. It appears I went straight to the top! La Santaneca on 24th and Mission was spectacular. An establishment that clearly has been a local favorite for a long time and definitely stands out among the plethora of latin choices in the Mission. The pupusas were fantastic and honestly every plate looked delicious. It did come with a brief wait as it seems they sustain a crowd for most every meal, but that brief wait should be evidence enough that its definitely worth it!
author: Brett N.

description:
Pretty awesome place. The Papusas were really good and this is my favorite papusa place of choice.

A definite must!
author: Eric A.

description:
I really liked the pupusas from here, they were really good!  I ordered a couple of the pork, cheese & beans w/loroca and it came with some curtido on the side and I would have to say this was one of the better pupusas I've had in quite a while.  

The only reason of the minus one star is that it took way too long for the food to arrive after we ordered.  Also, the waiter didn't seem too attentive when it came to refilling our cups of water unless you caught their attention and spoke up.  If I could rate this place on the food alone, it would be 5 stars, but the service definitely needs some improvement.
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
I love papusas!! Ever since I discovered them at street fairs..I have been on the look out for good papusas. 

Today, my good friend Jaime took three of newbies to La Santaneca. A San Francisco native and Salvadorean, James vouched that this place has damn good papusas. He wasn't lying. He ordered us each three different kinds of Papusas and other authentic dishes and beverages to try. I love the fried yucca and pork dish! It was topped off generously with a cabbage salad. All the delicious food was washed down by a refreshing Salvadorian soda and a cinnamon flavored drink. 
We ended of meal with a some pineapple pastries. 
During our meal I studied the menu and found several other dishes I would love to try..not to mention the enticing dishes that were being pated on other people's tables. Unfortunately my tummy ran out of room. I guess I will have to wait for trip #2..Lunch anyone?
author: Mimi T.

description:
If my review were based solely on their pupusas, this review would be 5+ stars.  I know pupusas, and this place really has the best pupusas in the Mission (especially when you factor in cost).  In fact, I have been going to this place for going on three years, so definitely worth going.  In fact, I pretty much refuse to get pupusas anywhere else.

The tamales I thought are ok (i say this because I prefer the ones my mother makes to any other tamales I've ever had).  Plantains are awesome as well.

So why, you ask yourself, am I giving this place three stars instead of five?!?  Well, there is one very important reason.  The service there has been declining.  Whenever I have the great pleasure of having the one female waitress employed by this place, my service is amazing.  Everything is promptly delivered, as ordered.  Unfortunately, the last half dozen times I've had one of their male servers (slightly older, balding) who just doesn't cut it.

Every single time I've been there, he has forgotten to bring me my water.  This may seem petty, but when you ask for water, wait 20 minutes and it still hasn't been brought out, that is a problem.  The first time I didn't really think too much of it.  The second time was the same.  The third time, I realized that the same waiter had done the same thing the two prior occasions.  Every time since then I've had the same issue with him.  It has gotten to the point that last time I had to tell the waitress that I love how amazing she was and how next time I was going to make sure to ask for her to wait my table.

So, will this make me go to another pupuseria? HELLS NO.  I love this place.  Does it annoy me that I can't ever seem to get this guy to give me water?  Of course.  Does it pain me to give my favorite pupuseria 3 stars? Yes, but such is life :(
author: Banana S.

description: I have always eaten at this place and always been pleased with the pupusas. But today i was disappointed The pork pupusas tasted like the pork was going bad. On top of it i took some to my co-workers and they didn't like them either. I just hope I don't get sick.
author: Ivy P.

description: Service is a bit slow but the wait is worth it. Get a pupusa and the platano frito with sour cream, love it!!
author: Marlo M.

description:
I went here for some papusas, as recommended by a couple of friends.  I tried 3: the cheese, pork, and mixed (pork and cheese) to see how each one differed. They all did and they were fantastic.  The pork is rich, the cheese is slightly gooey, and the mixed was the best of both worlds.  Don't forget the slaw.

At the end of the meal I exclaimed, "This is filling!" in food coma fashion.  Fantastic for the price, therefore they are OUTSTANDING 5 stars. Go give La Santaeca your business now!   

The horchata isn't anything to ignore either.
author: Neil E.

description: First time having pupusas. Sure - meat, cheese, and beans in cornmeal dough, what's not to love? They're perfectly fine, but that's it. Nothing about them is special or unique. Would've rather had a burrito at almost any local joint. Waited a half-hour for the food. Decent service, other than the wait. Excellent melon water, but that's available at any taqueria here.
author: Joe G.

description:
Walked upon a hidden gem (in my eyes). I've passed this place so many times, but never thought to drop in. So glad I did. Came here with 3 other adults and 2 kids - we ordered a lot, and ate EVERYTHING.

- rice and beans were flavorful and delicious
- beef tongue was surprisingly tender and flavorful
- the papusas were AWESOME, especially when eaten with the sauce and pickled cabbage
- plantains were fresh, juicy, and served hot. 

Service was fast and super friendly. Delicious food, must try it out!
author: Carol L.

description:
I love this place!

For about $6 I get to over feed myself a couple of Chicharrón papusa's with beans and rice. The Papusa's are being constantly made in the kitchen ALL DAY LONG which makes me feel good that they're not just grabbing it from the freezer.

I just wish the place was open later at night and things would be a lot cooler if they served beer.

Drinks side, the guava is tasty but the horchata is a little light on the cinnamon.
author: Keith A.

description: Best pupusas in the Mission, possibly the best anywhere ever, and yes I've gone to the trouble to sample every pupuseria between 14th and 30th Street before writing this review. Never tried anything else on the menu because those pupusas are just too irresistible. The homemade coleslaw is so more-ish and the perfect vinegary salty crunch served with the pupusas. Perfection for $2.00 or less. If only this place stayed open later than 8pm on weeknights!
author: Nacho C.

description:
Like a lot of other posters, I think La Santaneca De La Mission's pupusas are great. DON'T JUST LIMIT YOURSELF TO THE PUPUSAS, though you'll be doing yourself a great disservice.

Shorty and I were making the rounds to the various and sundry tschotskerias on Mission the other day when Shorty started making these sad little half-clucking noises, which when asked Shorty said were the noise chickens make when they freeze to death. Shorty then elaborated that every day hundreds of thousands of chickens were cruelly frozen to death in the name of stocking our supermarkets with frozen chickens. Rather than trying to delve into all the intermediate steps like depriving the chickens of their god-granted feathers and giblets, I decided to take Shorty somewhere where we could fill Shorty with something warming and reviving.

Consequently we stopped in at LSDLM and bypassing the pupusas, opted for big bowls of caldo (soup), for Shorty Caldo de Camarones (shrimp soup) and for me Caldo de Patas (pigs foot soup). For $9-10 we got huge bowls of soup. Shorty's featured a richly seafood flavored tomato-colored broth and 8-10 large shell-on shrimp (no heads much to Shorty's disappointment -- probably went to making that great broth) and a couple of good sized knots of scrambled egg. Mine had several big chunks of pigs feet, sawed into easily manageable pieces, squares of beef tripe, and a piece of corn and a big chunk of yucca in a menudo-like red-chile spiked broth (it also came with a small dish of chopped onions and cilantro). Factory-made, but nicely griddle toasted corn tortillas came on the side, we also split a Pastel de Carne, a deep fried ball of minced beef and potato wrapped in some kind of dough and served at center of the sun like temperature. All really good stuff.

Extra credit for their ultra-clean bathroom which you access by walking by the cadre of women patting out and slapping pupusas on the massive griddle. Only minuses would be the crowding if you don't time things right, the store-bought tortillas, and the can be forgetful (this time they weren't) service.

Good stuff, and Shorty isn't making tragedy-stricken chicken noises anymore.
author: Ed T.

description: If you want the best pupusas in the bay area.. scratch that in Cali come here!! Hands down the best pupusas I've ever had and I've had them all through California due to the fact i love me some authentic Salvodorian pupusas. Cheap and so worth it! I get the combo 2 pupusas w/ rice and beans on the side and that fills me up! The waiters are very welcoming especially if they remember you! LOVE LOVE this place. Right off of 24 st mission bart station you literally cross the street towards McDonalds and your there! Come to La Santaneca for the best pupusas in Cali!!! Pupusa WORLD!!!!!
author: Claudia G.

description:
This was a decent place for a light dinner and reminded me that I'd been here once before, a couple years ago. The pork/cheese pupusa was tasty, as was my chicken tamale, though both would benefit from a little more seasoning. I got a bite of a chicken enchilada and agreed that there was a flavor that seemed odd; I thought it might have been a slightly musty tortilla. My horchata seemed a bit grainy, like cocoa or kool-aid when not all the powder got fully dissolved.

Still, I was reasonably happy and satisfied with the portions and price, and the staff were friendly, even when informing me that they only take cash.
author: Bill B.

description:
Sign reads: bathroom on the back.
and yet placed so very strategically right under the menu.
I was so looking forward to eating papusas. It's not everyday I find myself at a papuseria. I ordered, they came, I ate. And it was not long till I was in the bathroom on the back. The food was fast looked good and tasted good but did not sit well with myself or the party that accompanied me. So no, I did not get a bad papusa.
author: RICARDO R.

description: PUPUSAS!!!  Hands down the best I've ever had. I get the ones with pork, cheese, and beans- We usually order 5 pupusas, horchata for two and an empanada and the bill is always less than $20. I drive all the way from San Rafael just to eat them.  I absolutely love this place!!!!!
author: Robin R.

description:
3 pupusas for $6. Doesn't get any better than that.

A friend brought me here for my first pupusa experience ever and omg, it was a fantastic experience. I ordered a plain pork, a pork with beans and cheese, and a pork with cheese and LOVED these little warm pockets of goodness!

I topped my pupusas with the deliciously spicy, tangy slaw and a light drizzle of hot sauce...HEAVEN! We had to wait awhile for our food to arrive, but it was totally worth the wait.
author: Karena Q.

description:
This place was a HORRIBLE experience. 
Slow service and food took forever, NO CHIPS N SALSA and loud as hell!

Food was not worth the wait. Too salty and not very authentic  If you're in the mission, keep looking...there's so much more to choose from. 

Limited menu and cash only.
author: Christos L.

description: In my opinion, best pupusas in the city. Although, I have noticed an increase in their prices.
author: Nemesis J.

description: Cheap authentic pupusas that taste awesome; this is a plus for my student budget :) though they are known for their pupusas, they have different options as well such as sopas and dish combinations so no need to feel limited to their pupusas in case you're not into that x)
author: Jessica G.

description: Cheap and delicious pupusas!  I went with a friend tonight, and we got two pupusas apiece with one bottle of sangria soda.  All for $10...there oughta be a law against that!!
author: C L.

description: Muy rico pupusas, like abuelas cocina. Seriously this place is so awesome, and super close to the 24th and mission Bart exit.
author: Renato S.

description: The food was delicious. My wife and I wanted to grab a bite to eat and after reading the other Yelp! reviews I was determined to try the pupusas. The cabbage and salsa had a great flavor. She got the Chile Relleno de carne. Both were excellent choices and I would go back in a heartbeat for Salvadorean food.  It doesn't get any more authentic then this place and it was super cheap too!
author: Josh M.

description:
The pupusas are good. But the pastel de carne was the best! I like the yuca too, but next time I should order it without chicharron because it's not my favorite. 
The walls are also adorned with great artwork from El Salvador.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I can't stop going back to this place and I constantly crave the cheese-oozing, pork-filled pupusas.  and the price!  can't beat it.  yesterday my boyfriend and I went for lunch and got 3 pupusas, an order of rice and beans, and fried plantains- all for $16 including tip and we were so stuffed we could hardly walk out of the restaurant...  

I've never tried the Salvadorian dinners- the menu for which is pretty extensive- because I am always so satisfied by the mix-and-match lunches I can create from the pupusa and side dish menus.  One thing I know for sure, though, is that there is something to please everyone.  The atmosphere isn't fancy but I couldn't care less- that makes for cheaper food that is always reliably delicious.
author: Luthien N.

description:
This place is just OK. There are so many better places in the mission.

I would go to el farilito any day before I go here.

I had some grilled chicken thing and it was SO DRY. Won't be going back here.
author: Josh D.

description: I have to say the best "PUPUSERIA" around. They have the best pupusas in the bay area, filling is perfect you can taste the cheese, the chicharron the beans the lorocos etc.. like if you were in El Salvador. I would say that if you really want to make your money worth eating pupusas, this is the place to go. You probably have to wait a little bit, the service is ok but is all compensate it when they bring the food to you and start endulging it. Such a great experience!!!
author: Julio N.

description:
My first experience with Salvadorean food and beef tongue. For a hole in the wall, this place exceeded my expectations. Service was friendly, the place was clean, and the ingredients looked and tasted fresh. The food is tasty and is made to order and so if you're looking for a quick eat, this is not the place to go (the menu even says to expect an average wait of 20 minutes for your food).

Beef tongue, I now know, is a very soft and tender meat. It's good, but if you want more texture, you'd probably want to stick to your typical meaty things.

As a tip, this place DOES NOT accept credit cards! There is are banks nearby, but still, it'd be better to bring cash. Average dish is a little over $10 so plan accordingly!
author: Wendy S.

description:
Since I first had my first pupusa a few weeks ago, I've been craving them like crazy. I came across this restaurant as I was Yelp-surfing and decided to come try this place. 
First and foremost, the pupusas are just as delicious as everyone has been saying. I got the pork and cheese ones and they were huge! And they were filled with goodness! I got three pupusas thinking I would still be hungry but boy was I stuffed by the time I was done with my second one. Also, it is super cheap! One pupusa is only $1.75! The plantains were also delicious. I really like the taste of their beans here and my best friend loved their rice. 
However, the service was only alright. They were friendly but didn't really check on us and the service was really slow. It took them 20-30 minutes to bring our food out and there weren't that many people at the restaurant. 
Besides the slow service, I would definitely come here again to get delicious pupusas. I would also like to try some of their other dishes.
author: T L.

description: What can I say - fantastic pupusas.  Stumbled in here once my hunger had overwhelmed my ability to decide what to eat, and was very pleasantly surprised.  Pickled cabbage and great salsa.  My only regret is that I didn't eat more.
author: Clint H.

description:
Love this place! First came here with my parents and now I love bringing my buddies here too and they always love it too.

I always, always, always get the chicharon and fried yuca appetizer.  Delicious.  Always a pupusa or two to share with whomever I'm with as well in addition to our entrees.  Never disappoints!
author: Marco S.

description: Best pupuseria in the Mission. Service is a little slow, but it is completely worth it. Wish they sold beer. Yuca con chicharon is pretty bomb too. Space is small and hot, they need some ventilation.
author: Roberto M.

description:
Best place for pupusas.
Best place for tamales.
Best place for fried plantains.
Even if it means taking BART from the East Bay.
The service, while friendly and warm, was a little slow. I look forward to returning when I am not in a rush to get somewhere.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: I LOVE this place! I'm Salvadorian and I travel to El Salvador often so I know what salvadorian food is suppose to taste like and most def La Santaneca takes this one! I've been to a few other spots and no one beats this place. The pupusas are the best (pork, cheese & beans) Don't really order anything else but have tried other stuff. The Horchata is really good as well. I love how they remodeled it the place.. If I'm on mission I stop and have some pupusas!
author: Jennifer M.

description: I would venture to say that they serve the best papusas in the Mission.  Not to mention their fried plantains.  The fact that it is right next to BART, so I can pop over on a whim only adds to my love for this place - and my current craving.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Located near the McDonald's on 24th street and Mission, this place is actually pretty good!
Offering both Mexican and Salvadorian cuisine, this restaurant has a lot of food options, even for breakfast.

I personally had a Salvadoreño steak, which was very tasty and came in large portion for a cheap price. Other entrees my friends had were also very good, such as the soup or the famous papusas!

The only regret about that place is the lack of alcoholic drinks (especially beer and alcoholic sangria!), but otherwise it's a very good option.
author: Bruno P.

description:
This place is amazing it has the best pupusas ever lol the customer service is great and so is the atmosphere, but I don't recommend the bathroom to tall people cause the ceiling was very low and I'm 5'7" but other wise absolutely great food also their are some treats in a plastic display box make sure you get the round tart it was buenísimo ( BTW I'm Spanish) also they only take cash but there is an ATM across the street literally right in front. so anyways if your looking for an authentic Spanish themed restaurant you know where to find it 
2815 Mission Street, San Francisco, CA 94110-3907 lol
author: Jose D.

description:
The place is cute, it's always hella packed and sometimes you have to wait for a table, but it's a short wait. The menu impressed me, LOTS of delicious salvadorian food.

I came here with my friends after a long night of drinking. I ordered my usual 2 pupusas de chicharon con queso y loroco. They were pretty damn greasy and pupusas should NOT be greasy at all. I ate them because well.. what's the best thing for a hangover?? GREASY FOOD!
I liked their curtido and that's about it. I'm sure a lot of people like it but go to panchitas 3, it's damn good there.
author: Debbie P.

description: The pupusas were okay, but the banana pastries were amazing.
author: Carly V.

description: I used to live and work in San Francisco and loved the Mexican and Salvadorean food in the Mission. I got hooked on pupusas.  I now live in the East Bay, and when I need my pupusa fix, I hop on the Bart and meet a friend at La Santaneca (24th and Mission).  I've been there several times and I'm probably their "biggest fan."  It's loud!  People are laughing, talking and eating great food.  It's not fancy and you have to pay cash!  There's no alcohol!  Trust me, you'll survive!   I go for the pupusas.  They are to die for!
author: Blondie R.

description: So the BF and I just left this place and it was so good I had write a review as soon as I was able to feel my fingers from having to walk in the freezing cold! It's a little hole in the wall restaurant, with amazing food. The pupusas did not disappoint. And they're great portions for very cheap. It was 25 bucks out the door including tip for the both of us. The reason I gave four stars, actually there's two. One is that although the waiters were polite they were otherwise indifferent. It also got extremely packed right after we arrived maybe that's why? And secondly while we were eating there was a lady in the already too crowded restaurant asking for money for some charity? Can I please eat my meal with out feeling guilty? After I told her no she proceeded to ask my boyfriend to donate.... Um hello?! No. It would be nice if they had a no soliciting sign somewhere and didn't allow people to come in and do that. Over all the experience was great food was awesome I know we'll be back!
author: Bae G.

description:
Pupusas!  
We had a craving for pupusas, and then we couldn't pass up trying the fried plantains.
The pork & cheese pupusa vs the bean & cheese pupusa...surprisingly (we're big pork fans) the bean & cheese was victorious! Was delicious, the beans make it! The pickled cabbage and sauce were good too, but think the cabbage could have a little more to it. The pork & cheese pupusa was still good, but the pork had less flavor than the beans.
The fried plantains, beans and sour cream appetizer was sooo good, the plantains were cooked perfectly, we just wish there were more beans with it ;) it's a must! Will definitely be ordering this again!
Definitely a great stop in the mission, convenient to BART, friendly staff, and a quaint little place in the heart of the mission district of SF! We'll definitely be back!
author: Jennifer T.

description: good food. good service. came for the pupusas and we weren't disappointed. not greasy like some places make them.  I tried the Arrayan which is wild guava drink.. Too sweet and gritty but I'll try the mamey next time.
author: J B.

description:
So I saw on the 7x7 that Pupusas was on the list--went there and it was just okay. However, this place hit it home. It was really delicious and I'm happy that it's right next to Bart. 

I've been eating pupusas since I was a kid and this place took me back to the good old days.

Super satisfying and will definitely come back here again.

:)
author: Tina T.

description: Best pupusas hands down!  I wish I lived closer...
author: Melissa L.

description: I love this place! My parents found this authentic eatery as teenagers and we've come to eat here regularly ever since. I live in Sacramento and I can't find a place as good as this one! Every time I come to SF, one of my first stops is to La Santaneca. Everything tastes the same; very consistant. The best Salvadorean food I've had =)
author: Jessica C.

description:
Really, it deserves 1 star for my dinner.  However, I suppose I deserved it.  

I ordered off the mexican menu section at a salvadorian restaurant.  However - if you are going to have a mexican section, you should at least try to make it better than what I had tonight.

I had the chile rellano.  I really like this and have had it a great number of times.  This was the worst.   It was in a very runny 'see through' thin sauce and the chile itself was total goo and had a bad texture.  The beans were a goopy pureed paste, and the rice was just rice.

I considered having one bite and paying the check but I thought that would be rude and well, if I didn't order the pupusas at a place like this I suppose I made my bed and deserved to lie in it.

Not returning, except maybe to try one of their pupusas some day.
author: Jason H.

description: This place is great. My family is all from El Salvador and have always loved this place. I do not come here often, but when I do its heaven! The pupusas are just as good as my mothers!
author: Stephanie F.

description: Best pupuas I have ever had in life! They have many different choices (meat/cheese, bean/cheese, etc.) and they are made  fresh to order. The cabbage slaw they serve with it is always nice and vinegary, yet still crunchy. I usually call-in my order here because they can get pretty busy. This place is worth trekking on BART from Oakland to get pupas.My step-dad is from El Salvador and agrees that these taste like "home" to him.
author: Nicky E.

description: Clean little place in the midst of not so cute area. Great service! The cheese pupusas were wonderful but I can't recommend the pork. Can you say salty ass manteca! Plantain empanada was bland. Of course you have to circle around  for 30 minutes to find parking.
author: E. Y. G.

description: definitely THEEE best papusas I've had. mmm. I want some now!
author: KevMo G.

description:
The chicharron (pork only) papusa was interesting and new, but the meat was a little grainy.  The crunchy slaw and the red sauce added complementing flavours and texture to the dish, which was brilliant.

I also had a prawn soup, recommended by the waiter who did not speak much English.  The soup was flavourful and saturated with the taste of shrimp -- great!  Unfortunately, the shrimps (they are not shelled, I'm indifferent about this) were extremely overcooked and tasted like rubber.  The soup came in two sizes, and I was told the only difference was the number of prawns.  I am definitely getting small next time.
author: Bill T.

description:
i was definitely impressed by la santaneca.  the food is so cheap and SO good, i would totally want to come back.

we shared the two pupusas with beans and rice (we got the two different mixed pork pupusas) and the fried plantains with beans and sour cream.  seriously, so good.  everything was really tasty without being overly greasy and the flavors were excellent.
author: Lisa C.

description: With so many restaurants in the area, you know this place must be decent if the lunch crowd is still waiting for tables at 1:30 on a Monday afternoon.  I chose this place as a meeting spot based on the reviews and was quite pleased with how it turned out.  Most of us went with Salvadoran dishes to try something different--they had a very flavorful and tangy taste you don't have in Mexican food.  I had the steak while others ordered the chicken with mushrooms and imitation crab enchiladas.  Servings were generous, and everyone was pleased! We also ordered a tamale and empanada as appetizers (both vegetarian for the pescatarian at our table).  They were also yummy.  You have an option of "fried or boiled" for the tamale...always go with fried!  It was pouring down rain so they offered bags for our umbrellas.  Definitely a good place to go on a rainy day.  Also doesn't hurt that there is a public parking lot around the corner (if you have to drive) and a BART station steps away.  If you like things quiet, this place has a lot of ambient noise.  I didn't mind at all since we were able to have our conversation just fine.
author: Karen J.

description:
Absolutely the best Pupusa's in the Bay!!  I drive from San Jose to come here.  Why?!  #1 Pupusa's are NOT greasy at all.  Been to other places where taste is good but grease is all over the plate.  #2 Taste, filling and size are more than plentiful, tasteful and reasonable.  #3 This should prob be reason 1 but, super cheap for a tasty well made authentic Pupusa.  This is coming from someone who's partly of Salvadorian descent and has been to El Salvador to have Pupusa's.  Moms a Salvi and she's a fan!!!  However I recently introduced someone who's American to Pupusa's and to this restaurant and they were instant fans!!  Loved the Pupusa's de frijoles con queso, chicharron con queso and platanos.  But to my surprise he couldn't stop talking about the chicken enchilada...  It was only one but was large and loaded high and wide w/ chicken and topped w/ plenty of cheese and sour cream.  He couldn't get over how delicious, fresh and hot it was when it hit his mouth!  Now I need to expand and try the rest of their menu.

4 stars only because it's cash only so you have to be prepared and customer service sometimes lacks.  Aside from that excellent food!!
author: Liss A.

description: Best pupusas from a restaurant (because no one beats my mom's pupusas)!!! The cheese is nice and guey, the chicarron is mearty, and the loroco is perfect. They are soooooo good that you will want to start ordering other things off the menu, which we did. The yuca frita was nice and crispy and the chicarron was to-die-for.  The platanos fritos are perfectly sweet. Every friend (Salvi and not) that I have ever brought here has loved this place.  Even my verry Salvadorena mother-in-law approved. Check this place out it is amazing!!!
author: Grizzy M.

description:
This is the super papuseria!  

I thought I didn't like papusas until I came here! These don't even compare with other places -- they are that good, and only about $2 each. The papusas salsa is runny, slighty vinegary, not too spicy, and is the best in the Mission.

I also had a fake crabmeat enchilada that was awesome and the fried plantains were also great. The horchata is very unique and has sesame seeds, isn't too sweet, and is muy authentico. 

Only La Pancha has better papusas.
author: Adam Z.

description: It's true that the pupusas here are very good, as are the hand-made tortillas.  If you're going to eat here, I'd stick to these.  I, unfortunately, ordered the sopa de rez instead (as I usually do), and it left a lot to be desired as the quality of the meat was terrible, the broth wasn't very flavorful, and there was a fair layer of grease floating on the surface.
author: Zain K.

description:
God I wish I had a pupusa right now...or just half of one. Topped with delicious pickled cabbage, hot sauce, and oozing with pork, beans, and cheese. 

It's the battle of the Santanecas. For the past year, since I discovered pupusas, I have been loyal to La Santaneca up near the Bernal/Excelsior side of Mission St. However, yesterday, I was just a block from THIS location, so I thought I should pick some up for dinner. 

Well...

The verdict is in: The pupusas here are bigger, tastier, and more expensive ($2.00 each for la revuelta con frijol). I did a to-go order and it took less than 10 minutes for my 9 pupusas.

I wouldn't like to stay and eat at the restaurant though...it's too stuffy and humid inside (poor ventilation). It has a nice ranchero-cowboy-vaquero theme going though.  

Pupusas=yummers

CASH ONLY--EFFECTIVO
author: Misha F.

description:
3 words: PUPUSAS and FRIED PLANTAINS!

They are among the best in town and only cost $1.75 -2 each. I usually get the pork, bean, and cheese or just the plain cheese. They are served with the slaw, salsa and sour cream on the side. Very tasty and super cheap.
author: Rex D.

description:
Best pupusas in town!
I have been going to this restaurant for 10+ years and refuse to go somewhere else for pupusas.  Their food is always fresh, delicious and cheap.  Make sure to try the tamales and platanos as well.  You will be really glad you went to this authentic Salvadorean spot.
author: Sofia A.

description: Went for the papusas.  These are better than Balompie's!  They are larger with more filling.  The plantains are devine!  The crutido needs more vinegear, but overall, this was a great experience and the food was  yummy and filling without being greasy.
author: Sandy H.

description:
Pupusas are like the stuffed-naan of El Salvadorian cuisine - torn, dipped, eaten with your hands.  And they're sooooo yummy.  I had the bean and cheese; my companion had the bean, cheese and pork; both were fantastic.  Each pupusa is about 6 inches in diameter and about 1/2 - 1 inch thick, and only $2.  I'd order 2 or 3.

Don't foolishly waste your appetite on chips or a tamale.  Just stick to the pupusas.
author: Tessa M.

description:
Well, I don't care for this place period, but my friend suggested we go here instead of Las Palmeras, so we did. First of all, service sucks, SUCKS! but I got over it. Crowd is "different" 

I ordered my pupusas, yeah, tasty, not bad, until I took a bite and guess what? I found a chunk of GLASS in it! I spit the damn thing and call the waitress and she still has the balls to question it! "Fuck you" was my attitude, just wanted to pay and leave and NEVER come back! 

Las Palmeras rock!
author: Anabelle B.

description: Some of the best pupusas in the country. I've ate them at alot of places and i'm proud to say San Francisco has the best pupusas besides El Salvador.
author: Daniel R.

description:
Came here for breakfast after a Sunday morning Taiko class at Dance Mission.

Sometimes I want beans with my eggs and tortillas instead of toast.  This place has one of the better dining atmospheres and, as far as a Mexican-style breakfast, delivers just fine.
author: Molly T.

description:
WTF?  That is the question I have been asking myself.  Why the F#$% have I not been here in years, decades actually. 

This is one of those places that makes me nostalgic for the 'good ol days.'  Way back when my cares in this world were what toy was I going to con my parents out of buying me or what radio station was I going to play in the Aerostar van.  Oh and my sibling's and I were brats too, my parents were nostalgic for food from the motherland and we never were so this place was convenient, they could buy us happy meals right next door, ha!

Anywho I decided to try it again, an acquaintance of mine had told me he LOVES the pupusas here and I said what the hell, lets give it another try.  I ordered a couple pupusas and an authentic Salvadorean horchata.  The pupusas were excellent!  The curtido (cabbage slaw) was on point, with peppers, a very nice kick.  The service was good, cute waiter, attentive and quick.  I am a fan once again, why I quit I will never know.  Now I have too many choices in SF for pupusas, this place is so convenient, you literally walk into it from the Bart station.

Now I feel like Barbara Streisand, "memories..."
author: La C.

description:
This place is da bomb.   The puposas are so big and tasty, and the cabbage slaw served with them is tangy and crunchy - yum.  

Only caveat:  Watch out for the gang members who hang on the corner.
author: .Hon H.

description:
According to an online review, apparently this place has been open since the 1980's, although you would never know that stepping into it's clean, somewhat modern interior. Located at the intersection of 24th Street and Mission Street in San Francisco, it may be difficult to spot this "diamond in the rough", hole in the wall restaurant. If you haven't had food from El Salvador, specifically pupusas, give La Santaneca a try. 

At about $1.75 each, the pupusa is a round, flour/corn treat wrapped around your choice combination of chicharron (pork), refried beans, chicken, or cheese. It is served with the native vegetable mix, a shredded, cabbage-like vegetable with a pickled taste.(in addition, I like to spread salsa over the pupusa as well). Definitely different. Most newcomers to pupusas underestimate the density of these little pupusas and order too much. I think the average person should be satisfied with two, maybe three at most. Also your meal is served with chips and spicy salsa. I don't know what it is about places that specialize in El Salvadorean food, but their salsa tends to be more runny as opposed to thick and chunky. Still, a delicious compliment.

The wait staff is friendly and accomodating. During busy times you may have to wait for a table or for your meal a little longer, but it is worth it, and you never have to wait a ridiculous amount of time. When all is said and done, you will be full from some of Santaneca's delicious pupusas, and even with a drink and their very delicious flan dessert you'll still have some money in your pocket to save for a rainy day.
author: Danny H.

description:
OK. So we came here just for the pupusas - to try them - because we love trying new foods - and now all of a sudden we're in love with them. And with La Santaneca - and with the ladies in the kitchen who so lovingly made them! Make sure you try the loroco flower one! And don't be afraid of the fried plantain - it's a bit weird to our eyes to consider fried banana, refried beans and sour cream, but trust me, delicious! 4.5 stars! Half off for the no beer thing...
Oh, and one more thing - I noticed during our meal that we were the only white people there - everyone else was Hispanic - and we left just as an older (50s) couple was leaving. I asked if they'd been here before & the lady said, "Oh yes. We're from El Salvador. This place has the best food from home. We love it here..."
author: Steve B.

description:
All I can say about this restaurant is that although it may not be for the vegan, it is an old world hole in the wall place.
