When my family first came here from El Salvador, we always went to this place. The food is not as good as my grandma's, but it is as close to it as I can ever come. 

Located right in the heart of the Mission District on 24th street, parking may be a difficult task, but if you enjoy good fatty food and a good time, this is the place to go.

Favorite Dish: 

Pupusas (Meat & Cheese) or Cheese and Vegetables.
Tamal de Elote con crema: Sweet corn tamle with Salvadoren sour cream
author: Ana S.

description:
A friend suggested La Santaneca for pupusas. I've been dying to try them so we trekked to the Mission....and promptly learned she meant La Santaneca in Bernal Heights. Oops.

No matter. We were hungry, and it looked tasty enough, so in we went. I do not claim to be a pupusa expert - in fact, this was my first experience - but our group LOVED our meals. Everyone got the two pupusa meal with rice and beans, and we were pleasantly surprised at the amount of food we received for a mere $5.50 each. And while La Santaneca's tortilla chips taste like they're fresh off a Safeway shelf, their salsa is really, really tasty.

Overall, it was a great, cheap, tasty meal in a convenient location, and it embodied two things I love about life in San Francisco: 1) you can find just about any ethnic dish you're dying to try, and 2) even when you arrive at the wrong restaurant there's a great chance the food is still terrific!
author: Beth T.

description: Where locals go for BOMB pupusas at a decent price!!!  Their curtido is perfect and I always order the sopa de camarones and platanos y frijoles y crema.  Omg, I'm salivating!  Love you guys!  Don't change a thing!
author: Humble T.

description:
Best pupusas in the Mission!
They also have a mean caldo de siete mares (seven seas soup).  YUMMY!!!
I've been here often and I'm always happily satisfied.
I don't think they serve any alcohol yet.
Luckily, they have a some fresh fruit juices like tamarindo, my favorite.
They are a small restaurant, very latin.  You go through the kitchen to get the the toilets...  LOL  the sort of thing you should not be surprise to see in the mission.
I love this tiny little place, and I would recommend it to anyone.
author: Yamil A.

description:
Yummy pupusas for $1.65 each. Service isn't the best (kinda slow and kinda non-existant after you get your food), but it's still a lot better than El Zocalo - at least I didn't have to wait half an hour for my food to come out.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: We just stumbled in here. It's a cute, clean-looking, hole-in-the-wall, which is about half full for Sunday brunch. It's a great full-service option for Mexican-style breakfast. They serve water out of the yellow 80's diner glasses. The coffee was a bit weak. I ordered a Salvadorean shrimp omelet. The food took a while to come out, but the servers were nice. The omelet was thin, browned, full of scallions and shrimp, and delicious. The corn tortillas were very warm and fresh -- and we asked for a side of fresh butter, which we put on them and that made it delicious. Also, my friend got something with platanos maduros. A little blackened and SO GOOD! On everything, I wish they took the salt one notch down. Overall, the place is a hidden gem. Avoid the rush at rival brunch spots and go for authentic.
author: Andrew K.

description: This place looks pretty good.  I am all over that Revuelta pupusas.
author: Jim J.

description:
Papusa heaven!

I could wax poetic, but really this can all be wrapped in three words: Quick, cheap, delicious - what more could you ask for?
author: Ennis O.

description: Thi!s place is bombing!  This is my official papusa hook up spot! The service is ok. Call ahead for take out!
author: Fatima Z.

description:
Love. love. love.

I bow to the pupusas that are oh so kind to my wallet. I adore these pancake looking but filled with chicharron goodness papusas. That spicy pickled cabbage and red sauce make me sigh with pleasure. I want it. Again. Maybe after I've recovered a little from my state of fullness. 

The shrimp enchilada plate was ENORMOUS! My eyes oogled that platter wondering where to start. The weird tiny shrimps were not exactly what I was expecting. I might try a different type of enchilada next time. 

Go hungry. Leave full. It's great.
author: Faye P.

description: They have such delicious food! I love their papusa and plate selections.
author: Wine L.

description: PAPUSAS and SOPA DE CAMARONES are so yummy!  The papusas are fresh and you can see the ladies making them in the back and guess what...it cost only $1.75 to $2.00.   Mainly, I come here to get my fixing of the hot shrimp soup...healthy and very filling.
author: Laureen M.

description: This is a good find! Very reasonable and the kitchen is open so you can see them prepare the food.  They seem to be pretty proper.  The food was very good - and not just the pupusas.  We had some grilled shrimp, el salvadorean tamales, and a fried item with meat inside.  Also, shrimp enchiladas.  I'm definitely going back.
author: Lana T.

description: This place was awesome.  I got their chicken plate (don't remember which), but it was just a large platter of goodness!  All the food was prepared and seasoned perfectly w/veggie, salad sides and enough food to fill me 3X over!  The hubby also loves their papusas, which he used to order for breakfast when he worked around the area.  I'm not a big fan of papusa, but it does taste quite good w/their vinaigrette coleslaw.  Overall great experience and service was very friendly and informative.
author: Julie W.

description: This was the first time I've had Salvadorean pupusas and they were dee-lishous!!!  I had the pork and cheese ones - so warm and oozy and perfect with the bright curtido and salsa.  I also ordered a chicken enchilada and my friend ordered some meat dish, but the pupusas were definitely the stars of the meal.  The place is small and minimal, but inviting enough and comfortable.  The service was friendly and I didn't notice the slow speed that people mentioned in other reviews.  Will definitely go back, especially at the extremely affordable prices!  Thanks Mr. Pollo for being packed that night, otherwise we might not have ever walked into this place.
author: Vicente G.

description:
This is a good example of SFGate/Yelping symbiosis.  I saw La Santaneca on the "Bargain Bites" section of SFGate.com but had to confirm with my fellow Yelpers for the low down.  And they were right, the place is good (Yelp) and cheap (SFGate).  

They have a good variety of papusas which I don't need to go into too much detail (see Pa P's review).  Their plantain appetizer and some kind of pork appetizer with yuca plant was well worth it.  Service was "slow", but only because they didn't shove the check in our faces at the end of the meal.  So I'm not one to complain...in fact I appreciated it!  

I'm definitely coming back.
author: Mark D.

description: LA SANTANECA that just sounds badass. Anyways this place is a pretty good spot to get some pupusas! I've been eating them since I was a kid (partly from being Salvadorean-American) and also because their yummy. I haven't tried this location until recently and was satisfied with their pupusas and service. The man took my order quickly and I got my food FAST like 10 minutes DONE. I ordered 2 revueltas and they were pretty fantastic, stuffed with cheese and pork just like i like it! Pork was a little salty but nothing to be over powered by. The awesome thing about pupusas is that their cheap and they get you full so their always welcomed in my diet! Definitely give it a try if your in the area!
author: Julio S.

description: I came to eat here for the first time. I have to say the pupusas are yummy. I ordered the rice kind instead of corn.  They had a lot of cheese and the curtido was mmmm good. The only issue I had was it gets packed and finding  a seat can be a bit of wait at times. Over all the pupusas are very tasty.
author: Eli R.

description:
I used to come to this place when I lived on Dolores Street and was hungover (the Sopa de Res is a perfect cure) and went there last night with a group of gals- most of whom were Latina.  I had wondered how it would be under the new ownership- they had completely re-done the place which sorely needed it.  And the food? A-mazing.  It is well documented here how wonderful the papusas are, and they did not disappoint.  I also tried the shrimp enchiladas- I have to say I have never had a better enchilada in my life- this truly melted in your mouth and had so much flavor!  The wait staff was great- they put up with a lot- we were catching up and were there for more than 2 hours, but they accomodated us.  The owner Jose was on hand making sure everything in the dining room went smoothly.  Also one of the cleanest restrooms in SF- definitely a plus!

I CANNOT wait to go back!
author: Trisha F.

description: In a word, good. Hook yourself up with a couple pupusas to go with rice and beans, reveling momentarily in the pleasures of an approximately seven-dollar bill. Now, for when you get home and open it up to feast, protip: the little baglet they put the salsa in is meant to be cut open carefully over a bowl or some other receptacle. Unless the object, of course, of your exertions is to coat all your napkins with salsa for some bizarre future use that you should just keep to yourself, thank you very much.
author: Peter B.

description:
For the life of me, I couldn't remember the name of this place.

Searching pupusa in Yelp, didn't find it either.  Almost tricked myself
into thinking it was Las Palmas, but La Santaneca.....  it's one of those names, when you hear it, you remember it.  

I had no idea there were other places in S.F. to find a pupusa, but pupusa's at La Santaneca are AMAZING.  It's a crime that they are so cheap, as I would willingly pay much much more.  Now if they could find away to package them like frozen pizza...  cause driving across town, finding a parking spot in the Mission, although worth it, could be construed as borderline obsessive.  But if you don't know what I'm talking about, you've definitely never had a pupusa from La Santaneca!
author: L. K.

description:
Cheese and beans pupusas.

That's all I eat here.

This was my first experience with pupusas, and still is my favorite pupusas place. 

The place is clean and people here are nice too.
author: Wakaknee J.

description: Pretty good. The pupusas are well priced at $1.75 each. They arent quite as soft as some Ive had in LA, but still very tasty. The place also has a nice atmosphere, unlike some of the downright frightening LA spots.
author: Kim R.

description:
Love this place! 

Great salsa, pupusas, horchata. Cheap, too.
author: J K.

description: I really wanted to give this place a high rating but the chicken was very salty, it was horrible. But I'm a big supporter of the smaller shops so I'll be back again, the staff can't really speak English but they were very nice.
author: Tiff W.

description: Recommend this great dish of eggs, fried plantains, rice & beans, sour cream, and tortillas. Plus the papusas were excellent.
author: Tammy K.

description:
La Santaneca serves up SF's best pupusas with a smile. These are essentially like Mexican gorditas but quite a bit thinner. After eating a substantial amount of food, I resolved it was the best thing on the menu. I plan on going back for a stacked plate of them-- piping hot and fragrant. 

The Sopa de Pollo was a perfect weapon against a looming cold but was a bit on the salty side. The fried yucca, plantains, and elote tamales (sweet corn) are certainly worth a try. I didn't care so much for the slaw but everyone seemed to be enjoying it on their pupusas.

I was a bit frustrated that the bill was illegible and wound up being miscalculated by over ten dollars-- but management was apologetic and resolved the matter quickly. 

Overall, our experience was positive and we found that even a vegan will have plenty to eat here-- if you don't mind the starch, that is! The waiter welcomed all of our questions despite how busy it was. 
Expect this tiny, clean place to be packed-- but it will be worth your while.
author: OKAY O.

description:
My boyfriend and I popped in for take out and ordered an enchilada and a tostada.  Not only did we wait for half an hour for our food, but it was awful!

The food was so bad, that it prompted me to finally join yelp and express my disdain for this establishment.
author: Katharine F.

description: Tried this place on a recommendation from a co-worker. Dropped by after Carnaval and was pleasantly surprised. I had the Pupusas (of course coming here and not ordering the pupusas is like going to Fentons Ice Creamery and not ordering ice cream!) which were well made and tasty. The pupusas combo plate (two pupusas with beans and rice) is affordably priced at just under $7. The tables were a little dirty, but what else would you expect from a restaurant on 24th and Mission. On the downside, the restaurant is a little small. Large groups should take the steps for extra planning if coming here to eat. Also, be sure to say hello to the cooks if you go the restroom since its located in the back of the kitchen. And don't worry. I was told the dishwasher gives everyone the "evil eye" when you walk back there. LOL
author: Black K.

description: I used to eat here 27 years ago and was back and could not resist going TWICE during my vacation. I love the Mission District and this is the all out best for pupusas. The wait staff is pleasant and efficient and there is no way I will miss this joint EVERY time I am in Frisco!
author: Karen W.

description: The pupusas were authentic and delicious.  Great deal.  The side of slaw is much better than can be gotten at similar restaurants.  Fried plantains were the perfect accompaniment.  Restaurant is clean and efficient.  Only drawback is there is no beer.
author: p w.

description: Still the best pupusas in town (sorry Balompie, it's da truth), though they take way long to make - order in advance if you can!
author: Ara S.

description: I've been coming here for years, and they have the best pupusas ever, i like them more than the one is El Salvador. All there food is of da hook. I try to come here every time I'm in the city. All in all this place is the best.
author: Moises M.

description: I've been coming to this place for years now, and today I decided to go out of the norm, and tried something other than pupusas. I tried the pan con pavo, which is a very delicious Salvadorean sandwich made with turkey in a sort of mole sauce, with mayonnaise, tomato, cucumber, watercress and pickled veggies on top. My sandwich at La santaneca was ok tasting but it lacked the authentic flavor of the original version. It didn't even have mayo on it, and instead of the pickled veggies, it just had lettuce on top. The pupusas are in my opinion good here, very close to the ones at home. Side dishes are pretty blah, not much to rave about. I also ordered an atol de elote and it did not have the usual corn kernels in it, so I was a bit disappointed. the flavor was OK, enough to quiet my craving for it. I am Salvadorean and I know my flavors pretty well, having lived there for many years. I have yet to find a Salvadorean place that truly conveys those flavors, and find it sad that these places claim to be "authentic". Over all an ok experience, but will not be taking bart into the city for it any time soon.
author: Laura P.

description: Just so you know, the enchiladas de cangrejo do NOT use real cangrejo (crab), (they only use the pink fake stuff)  I ordered the enchiladas for lunch and they are really cheesy (a point for cheese lovers), but I don't really like my enchiladas that cheesy, the order also came with salad, rice and a side of refried beans, I should have gone to El Farolito instead, but I walked by and Mr. Pollo wasn't open for lunch yet, so I thought I would try La Santaneca, maybe the pupusas are better.
author: Mark G.

description: Amazing pupusa with perfectly seasoned curtido. I prefer the pork only (chicharron). This place really REALLY heats up when it's warm in SF, you feel like you're on the streets of El Salvador.
author: Sarah L.

description: I've been here three times and twice i've had some of the best fried ripe plantains I've every had, really 5+ star material.  One time they were only good,  not superb.  The pupusas are my favorites in the city, tasty, not greasy.  Excellent Salvadorean food, and so convenient to the 24th street BART stop.
author: Dan J.

description: I L-O-V-E this place!!! I especially love getting their breakfast here! Being Salvadorian myself and living away from home and away from San Francisco, I always crave some delicious PUPUSAS and my traditional Salvadorian homemade breakfast...at La Santaneca I gotta get it all: platanos, casamiento (rice mixed with beans), huevos w/salsa (eggs), crema (sour creme), pupusas, curtido and horchata! :) I have tried several pupuserias and by far...this place has definitely impressed me! Their pupusas are stuffed just right and the cheese just melts right out! yuummmmm!!!!! I always leave satisfied and the service is great! Everyone there is so nice and welcoming!! I live in San Jose and I always crave their food...I never mind making a drive out there for some of their pupusas...it's that good that it's well worth the commute! :) I have fallen in love...
author: Claudia V.

description:
so my girlfriend and i happened in on this place while walking down mission on a saturday afternoon.  we weren't sure what to expect, but I was extremely impressed. 

why 4 stars?
* delicious food & horchata! (i had enchiladas de camerones)
* really friendly wait staff
* really quick service
* biodegradable to-go boxes
* the CLEANEST bathrooms i've seen in the mission

note: there was a big sign that said cash only, so i'm not sure why there are 4 votes for "accepts credit cards."
author: sam h.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE - the BEST PUPUSAS IN TOWN!!! Great service & great prices....it's a cozy, clean restaurant and the service can be a tad slow but they cook the food fresh and you should really go here to sit down, relax and enjoy your meal and your company. I found this place because I just so happen to have a mother that is Salvadorean and she knows the spots for some good Pupusas :) I def recommend this place...my husband likes the Pupusas and the fish, but didnt really care for the enchiladas...overall this is an awesome place!
author: Kimberly R.

description: This is an affordable place to get delicious Central American food. The dishes are not exotic but hearty and simple. Chicken or beef soup, back beans, fried yuca are some of my favorites.
author: Sandra W.

description:
Best salvadorean breakfast in the city. Platanos con Casamiento Huevos and a little cremita, i'm making myself hungry.

That said Ive never had their pupusas but they looked tasty, but pupusas arent the reason I come here, next time youre in line at Boogaloos or St Francis keep this place in mind. You wont leave dissapointed.
author: Arnold S.

description: My family and I have been coming here for the last 13 years or so. I hadn't been back here myself in a few years though. I noticed the restaurant has been remodeled. It has recessed lighting and new tables, looks cute. We never fail to find a good place to eat in the city, La Santaneca is an all time favorite. My favorite dishes here are the pupusas revueltas, yucca frita con pescaditos, atole de elote, pasteles de pollo and tamales salvadorenos de pollo. Everything is made to order so it takes a while to get your order but the wait is worth it. True, the wait staff could probably be friendlier but it seems they are understaffed. We went there on a Saturday for lunch and it was super busy, there were two waiters, two cooks and one dishwasher. The owner popped in for an hour or so and left. They had to tend to sit-in customers and take-out orders. They were going crazy!  I still give it five stars for great food!
author: Morena T.

description: The pupusas are really good and only $1.75 each, the citrusy cold drink is excellent and refreshing, but it's the fantastic chicken with mushrooms FTW!
author: Maximillian M.

description: This place is SO GOOD! Their pupusas are delicious and cheap plus they come with a spicy salsita and that delicious vinegary coleslaw, and the rest of their food is quality as well. The servers and everybody who works are really nice too. For dessert try some Salvadorean special treats, as well as their hot chocolate.
author: Gina R.

description: I love these pupusas.  I live a block away and I can't believe it took me so long to discover them. The first time we ordered the bean and cheese and accidentally got the everything pupusa- what a wonderful mistake- delicious! I have since had the bean and cheese too yummmm- I cna't wait to try all of them. Plus they are super cheap $1.65/pupusa. Two pupusas and some pickled cabbage is plenty to fill you up for dinner. Also the place has a great ambience and the people who run it/work there are really nice and friendly.
author: Jane K.

description:
So. good. I have been searching high and low for decent pupusas and I have finally found them: La Santaneca de la Mission has the most perfect pupusas I have ever known.

Also good: fried yucca, anything with platanos, and the breakfast calamientos plate... Stick with the Salvadorean fare here--you can get good Mexican food anywhere in the city but Salvadorean is harder to come by and this is where you get it!

OH! And the horchata here is amazing, obviously freshly made (unlike some places where they use a powder mix). Mmmmm.

I really like the place aesthetically, too. It doesn't have that fluorescent lighting that so many of the fast-food Mexican places in the Mission have. It's dimmer and so much more appealing. It's very clean, and it has sit-down service. The waiters are really really sweet. Also very fast! We got our food maybe 10 minutes (if that) after ordering.

NB: CASH ONLY.
author: Eva G.

description: We went with 4 people, had pupusas and a burrito and a steak and salad and...I forget what else.They were super friendly and the food was good. The bathroom was clean, the place seemed well tended.
author: jen n.

description:
Great place for pupusas.  The other reviews have a good description of them.  Two quite large pupusas plus rice and beans is $5.50. That's a deal.  Used to go to Balompie for my cravings, but this is a great option.
The empanada is fantastic.  Mashed sweet plantain filled with a huge amount of "milk" - basically milk pudding oozy yummy goodness mmmmmmm.  And it's fried.  If you like fried plantains, try this sometime.
The tamal de pollo was really good, too.  Very moist and steamy, and not at all bready.  There was some shredded chicken, potato (maybe yucca) strips, a few chickpeas and pepper.  It's not stuffed full of meat, but the masa was so flavorful and moist that I was glad to have more it that.  Fairly large.
You'll need to walk it off, but it tastes great.
No alcohol - not sure if that will change.
author: C G.

description:
Yummy.  The pupusas are so delicious and filling, and I like their spicy cabbage on the side.  The platanos are kind of overpriced for what you get, and boy are they greasy...not to say that's bad.

It's a very good deal for what you get.  Be warned that they close pretty early in the evenings, so don't just show up at 8:30 as you'll probably be out of luck.
author: Frank S.

description: I've been coming to this place for the pupusas since I was a little kid.  The pupusas are delish, cheap, and conveniently located across the BART station.
author: Rowzbud R.

description: i died and went to papusa heaven.  so conveniently located close to BART.  so yummy.  so tasty.  i love the way the cheese squirts out the sides on the grill so you get these chewy crusty bites of yummy fried cheese.  slow service (i believe this to be the hallmark of any good pupusaria) but who cares?  you need the time to build up the anticipation of the pupusa goodness to come.  plus, you don't want to be rushed anywhere after pupusa consumption.  it isn't good for the digestion.
author: Samantha W.

description: forget el zocalo, this place is the Shitznitz! i got all my friends hooked on it...hahaha! this is totally the best place for pupusas in SF!
author: Carolina M.

description: So don't tell the bf this..but i'm conceding that la santaneca makes the best pupusas in SF. It's such a cute little place, the people are nice, and everything is good. My faves: pupusas, fried plantains (I hate bananas...like deathly hate bananas...and love love love these plantains), their prawn sopa: all good. Even their beans are above average deliciousness (much to the bf's chagrin). I came here 3 days this week and still want to go back tomorrow!!!! Oh how do I love thee pupusas!
author: Emily W.

description: Nice hole in the wall, great service for a small restaurant. The pupusas were amazing with the melted cheese and beans. The platanos, so delicious, I ate everything on my plate. I'll definitely go back.
author: Lulabelle W.
